\#\#\# User: Although haters may slander PHP forever, one cannot deny the fact that [most of the web](https://w3techs.com/technologies/overview/programming_language/all) is powered by this language,
including portals like Facebook, Wikipedia, [WordPress](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WordPress), [Vkontakte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VK_%28social_networking%29)
and \- much more important \- a lot of lesser grade sites, written not with proprietary frameworks, like the above, but with Open Source libraries and tools.

* By 2016 PHP evolved into a mature [OOP](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming) language, with many up\-to date mainstream features borrowed from other languages.
* Several mature frameworks are on the scene, offering industry\-standard solutions or the tasks like authorization, database access, [REST](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_State_Transfer) services, etc.
* PHP exists in a strong and lively ecosystem, its [package manager](https://getcomposer.org/) offers thousands first\-class libraries.

From all the above one could tell that there are a lot of PHP professionals around, who are using modern tools and practices. But...

*looking into PHP tag on Stack Overflow, one would say that it's an awfully outdated language, stuck in early 2000s, with every single task performed manually, by means of re\-inventing the wheel in the form of an ugly, hasty, untested and unsafe on\-site sketch.*

So I suppose it is because PHP professionals seldom have time to answer questions, leaving the field for the *enthusiasts*.

Yes, formally we have top\-grade PHP contributors on Stack Overflow.
But they all took refuge in the chat room and you seldom can see them answering a question.

I cannot tell for the other tags but I suppose the situation is similar for all the widely\-adopted languages and technologies.

So the question is: how to make Stack Overflow a desirable platform for sharing knowledge?
How to make it home not only for people interested in the virtual points and badges, but for people, whose interest is different \- for those who have the knowledge and are willing to share it?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **Please note:** Following is my *personal* opinion after several years of PHP and [php](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/php "show questions tagged 'php'") experience, it does not represent Stack Overflow, or my actions as moderator. Sadly, I'm not going to offer a solution here, so if that's what you're looking for, skip this answer.

Stack Overflow, originally, was a site where experts came to ask each other interesting and engaging questions. The weaker devs were predicted (with great accuracy) to be attracted to the high level information, and participate, increasing their own skill levels.

The issue is that Stack Overflow then became steadily more popular, and especially in tags like [php](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/php "show questions tagged 'php'"), [jquery](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/jquery "show questions tagged 'jquery'") and others, we saw a huge degradation in quality, attributed to a decrease in signal:noise ratio, as well as experts giving up and leaving due to that same decrease.

This is a system\-wide problem. Stack Overflow, as the system currently stands, whether by design or not, is a compromise more in\-favor of the newbs, than it is of the experts. (Stack Overflow's quality levels are still well above the competitors, in my opinion)

* It takes 5 high rep users to close, and 1 no rep user to answer.
* It takes a user a long time to find and research, and no time to ask and have his question closed and pointing at the right one for him.
* Answerers are expected to answer concisely and Solve The Problem™. Asking "what have you tried" or pointed to google is frowned upon.
* etc

Some of these were out there since the beginning, some evolved because the expert\-oriented nature of the site was unfriendly to users.

I don't have a good solution for you. There's no magic powder you can coat [php](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/php "show questions tagged 'php'") in and suddenly make it interesting. People don't use PHP because it's shiny, people use it because it Solves The Problem™ and is easy enough to use. And just Solving The Problem™ doesn't really make for an interesting discussion.

This is an advanced stage in the life cycle of any community, what comes next... isn't good. I don't have the solution here, I don't think anyone on the internet does, if Stack Overflow manages to solve this problem, I'll take my hat off and clap.

There is no other expert community that had reach this size before. All of them imploded and died much sooner. We don't have anyone else to compare ourselves to, no one to learn the mistakes of. Which makes this all the harder to implement right. It's a matter of scale, and we would need to think carefully about every step we take.

The challenge is maintaining a balance between being accessible to newcomers while still attracting and retaining expert users who can provide high-quality answers.

\#\#\# User: I am trying to allow the user to be able to choose multiple records in a field on the search form.

Something like this:

```
<%= f.input_field :neighborhood_id, collection: Neighborhood.order(:name), :url => autocomplete_neighborhood_name_searches_path, :as => :autocomplete, 'data-delimiter' => ',', :multiple => true, :class => "span8" %>

```

It sends it to my `search` model like this: `@search = Search.create!(params[:search])`

This is what the `Search.rb` model does with it:

```
key = "%#{keywords}%"
listings = Listing.order(:headline)
listings = listings.includes(:neighborhood).where("listings.headline like ? or neighborhoods.name like ?", key, key) if keywords.present?
listings = listings.where(neighborhood_id: neighborhood_id) if neighborhood_id.present?
listings

```

The issue is that this is just accepting 1 `neighborhood_id`, so I am getting this error when I choose multiple objects:

```
undefined method `to_i' for ["Alley Park, Madison"]:Array

```

Where `Alley Park` and `Madison` are the names of 2 neighborhoods, not the IDs.

So how do I get this working?

Thanks.

**Edit 1**

The issue seems to not be in the lookup of the `params[:search]` per se, but rather in the conversion of the form input to an array of entries. I tried changing the search method to be something like: 

```
listings = listings.includes(:neighborhood).where("neighborhoods.name like ?", neighborhood_id) if neighborhood_id.present?   

```

Don't get hung up on the fact that I am looking up `neighborhood.name` and passing in `neighborhood_id`. I just did that because I know that the params for the field `neighborhood_id` were actually the names of the `neighborhood`. If this had worked, I would have refactored some stuff, but it didn't. So don't get hung up on that. 

But that still returns the error `undefined method 'to_i'....`

Also, I still get that error even if I just pass in 1 option.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
```
listings = listings.where("neighborhood_id in (?) ", neighborhood_id) 

```

1.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: When dealing with multiple selections in a Rails form for neighborhood IDs, which modification to the search query would correctly handle an array of neighborhood IDs without causing a "undefined method 'to_i'" error?

A) listings = listings.where(neighborhood_id: neighborhood_id.split(','))

B) listings = listings.where("neighborhood_id IN (?)", neighborhood_id)

C) listings = listings.where(neighborhood_id: neighborhood_id.map(&:to_i))

D) listings = listings.where("neighborhood_id = ANY(?)", neighborhood_id)

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B is the correct approach for handling multiple selections in a Rails query. The "IN" clause allows for checking against multiple values, and passing the array directly as a parameter ensures proper SQL escaping. This method works whether neighborhood_id is a single value or an array of multiple IDs.

Option A incorrectly assumes the input is a comma-separated string, which it isn't in this case.
Option C attempts to convert elements to integers, which would fail if the array contains neighborhood names instead of IDs.
Option D uses PostgreSQL-specific syntax (ANY) which may not work across all databases and is unnecessary here.

The correct option avoids the "to_i" error by treating the input as an array of values to be matched against, regardless of whether they are IDs or names.

\#\#\# User: If I inherit something, what has my father done to the something? I've found the word 'bequeathed' but I'm not sure that this is the colloquial word.

I need the word to describe a programming class from which another class inherits. Rather frustratingly, in no OOP papers can I find this word being used in English!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: *Inherit* in this case is not like passing down property upon death, it's more like passing down genes upon conception. In other words, *inheritance* in OO programming is not like inheriting your mother's antique sofa, it's more like inheriting your mother's blue eyes.

I would use the term *passed on* (or perhaps *passes along*), as we say that certain characteristics can be *passed on* from generation to generation:

> The attribute `balance` is inherited from the parent.  
> 
>  The parent class passes on the `balance` attribute.

There may be a better word for this, because parameters are also *passed*, but that's the first one that came to my mind, and it fits better than *leave to* this context.

NOAD lists this definition for *pass*:

> **pass** (*trans. verb*) be transferred from one person or place to another, esp. by inheritance : *infections can pass from mother to child at birth*

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In object-oriented programming, when describing the relationship between a parent class and a child class that inherits from it, which term most accurately describes what the parent class does with its attributes and methods?

A) Bequeaths
B) Passes on
C) Donates
D) Transfers

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B) "Passes on." This terminology aligns with the biological metaphor used in object-oriented programming, where inheritance is likened to genetic inheritance rather than the legal transfer of property. The documentation specifically mentions that "passed on" is an appropriate term, as it's commonly used to describe how characteristics are transmitted from one generation to the next.

A) "Bequeaths" is incorrect because it's associated with the legal transfer of property after death, which doesn't accurately represent the dynamic nature of OOP inheritance.

C) "Donates" implies a voluntary giving, which doesn't capture the automatic nature of inheritance in OOP.

D) "Transfers" is close but lacks the specific connotation of generational passage that "passes on" conveys.

The question tests understanding of appropriate terminology in OOP and the conceptual model underlying inheritance in programming.

\#\#\# User: I have a device (a popcorn popper) that has an L14\-20P plug.   

I would like to use it with my stove's 14\-50R receptacle.   

Since the device is rated for 20 Amp, and the receptacle for 50, this should be ok, or am I overlooking something?
And if it *is* ok, would the following be the correct wiring:

![image](https://imgur.com/0ytfdgl.jpg)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your wiring does match up the ground, neutral, and phases, so it would supply power, and since it is a 50 amp circuit it has more than enough juice for a 20 amp appliance, but it isn't really safe. The appliance and its cord etc. are designed to be safe with a breaker that trips at 20 amps, not 50\.

3.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An electrical engineer is attempting to connect a popcorn popper with an L14-20P plug to a stove's 14-50R receptacle. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this situation?

A) The connection is safe and appropriate because the receptacle can handle more current than the device requires.

B) The connection is unsafe due to the mismatch in amperage ratings, despite the correct wiring of ground, neutral, and phases.

C) The connection is safe as long as an adapter is used to convert the L14-20P plug to a 14-50R configuration.

D) The connection is appropriate if the circuit breaker for the 14-50R receptacle is replaced with a 20-amp breaker.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: While the wiring diagram shows correct matching of ground, neutral, and phases, and the 50-amp receptacle can supply more than enough power for the 20-amp device, this connection is unsafe. The key issue is that the appliance and its cord are designed to be safe with a circuit breaker that trips at 20 amps, not 50 amps. Using a 50-amp circuit for a 20-amp device removes an important safety feature, as the circuit breaker would not trip at the lower current that could potentially be harmful to the 20-amp rated device. This mismatch in amperage ratings creates a safety hazard, even if the wiring itself is correct.

\#\#\# User: I was wondering if this is possible: I received a game as Steam gift from a friend, but I'm not really interested about that game. If I do not claim/activate the game, is it possible to give it to someone else who has a Steam account? If so, how long can I keep the game without redeeming/activating it before sending it to someone else?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes you can re\-gift steam games, as long as you accept them as gifts into you inventory, not activate them for yourself. 

Games won't expire, but some items do (e.g. Coupons, beta access). Items that will expire say right in the description how long until they do. My coupon for 50% off Duke Nukem says

> (Valid until Mon Jul 01 2013 02:59:00 GMT\-0400 (Eastern Daylight Time))

After that, I believe it will disappear.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: A Steam user receives a game as a gift from a friend but is not interested in playing it. Which of the following statements is true regarding the gifted game?

A) The user can only activate the game for themselves or decline the gift, with no option to re-gift.
B) The user can keep the gift indefinitely in their inventory without activating it and re-gift it at any time.
C) The user must re-gift the game within 30 days of receiving it, or it will automatically activate on their account.
D) The user can re-gift the game, but only if they haven't claimed or activated it, and some gifted items may have expiration dates.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. According to the StackExchange documentation, users can re-gift Steam games as long as they accept them as gifts into their inventory without activating them. The games themselves don't expire, allowing users to keep them in their inventory indefinitely. However, it's important to note that some gifted items, such as coupons or beta access, may have expiration dates. These dates are typically clearly stated in the item's description. The other options are incorrect because: A) falsely states there's no re-gifting option; B) doesn't account for the potential expiration of some items; and C) incorrectly suggests an automatic activation after 30 days, which is not a feature of Steam's gifting system.

\#\#\# User: Show: $\\left(\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k\\right)^2\\leqslant (n\+1\)\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k^2$ for $n\\geqslant 0$ and $a\_k\\in\\mathbb{Z}\_{\\geq 0}$.

Wanted to show this by induction:

1. $n\=0: a\_0^2\\leqslant a\_0^2$
2. Assume it is shown for $n$, now show for $n\+1$.

$$
\\left(\\sum\_{k\=0}^{n\+1}a\_k\\right)^2\=\\left(\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k\+a\_{n\+1}\\right)^2\=\\left(\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k\\right)^2\+2a\_{n\+1}\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k\+a\_{n\+1}^2\\\\
\\leq (n\+1\)\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k^2\+2a\_{n\+1}\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k\+a\_{n\+1}^2\\\\
\\leq(n\+1\)\\sum\_{k\=0}^na\_k^2\+(n\+1\)a\_{n\+1}^2\+2a\_{n\+1}\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k\\\\
\=(n\+1\)\\sum\_{k\=0}^{n\+1}a\_k^2\+2a\_{n\+1}\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k\\\\
\\leq (n\+2\)\\sum\_{k\=0}^{n\+1}a\_k^2\+2a\_{n\+1}\\sum\_{k\=0}^n a\_k
$$

This is by the assumption.

Now how to continue?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **Hint:**

AM\-GM inequallity give us
\\begin{align\*}
a\_k(a\_0\+a\_1\+\\ldots\+a\_k\+\\ldots\+a\_n)\&\=\\sum\_{j\=0}^na\_ka\_j\\\\
\&\\leq \\sum\_{j\=0}^n\\frac{1}{2}(a\_k^2\+a\_j^2\)
\\end{align\*}

From this inequallity it follows $$a\_k(a\_0\+a\_1\+\\ldots\+a\_n)\\leq\\frac{n\+1}{2}a\_k^2\+\\frac{1}{2}\\sum\_{j\=0}^na\_j^2$$
Since $\\displaystyle{\\left(\\sum\_{k\=0}^na\_k\\right)^2\=\\sum\_{k\=0}^{n}\\left\[a\_k(a\_0\+a\_1\+...\+a\_n)\\right]}$, we have 
$$\\displaystyle{\\left(\\sum\_{k\=0}^na\_k\\right)^2}\\leq\\frac{n\+1}{2}\\left(a\_0^2\+{a\_1}^2\+\\ldots\+a\_n^2\\right)\+\\frac{n\+1}{2}\\sum\_{j\=0}^na\_j^2\=(n\+1\)\\sum\_{j\=0}^na\_j^2$$

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given proof:

Question: Given the inequality $\left(\sum_{k=0}^n a_k\right)^2 \leq (n+1)\sum_{k=0}^n a_k^2$ for $n \geq 0$ and $a_k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$, which of the following statements is true?

A) The inequality can be proved using only the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality
B) The proof requires the use of both induction and the AM-GM inequality
C) The inequality holds for all real numbers $a_k$, not just non-negative integers
D) The proof can be completed using the AM-GM inequality without induction

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality alone is not sufficient to prove this statement.
B is incorrect because while induction was initially attempted, the final proof doesn't require induction.
C is incorrect because the inequality is specifically stated for non-negative integers.
D is correct because the proof uses the AM-GM inequality to show the relationship between the terms, and this method is sufficient to prove the inequality for all n ≥ 0 without using induction.

The key insight is using the AM-GM inequality to establish that $a_k(a_0+a_1+...+a_n) \leq \frac{n+1}{2}a_k^2 + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=0}^n a_j^2$, which leads directly to the desired inequality when summed over all k.

\#\#\# User: I am trying to intuitively understand the Poisson regressions, but I don't get:

1. why the increasing variance along with the mean is relevant?
2. how each of these three theoretical Poisson distributions was shown here, i.e. using each Y value as a mean\=variance?

So far, my understanding is that for each Y a theoretical distribution is drawn, and then the best curve is fitted to maximize the cumulative probabilities (maximum likelihood?)

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Ewm9J.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Ewm9J.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 1. For $Y\\sim Poisson(\\lambda)$, $\\mathbb E\\big\[Y\\big] \= \\lambda$ and $\\text{Var}(Y) \= \\lambda$. If the mean of the conditional distribution increases, the variance of the conditional distribution must increase, too. If there is no such increase, too much increase, or too little increase, then Poisson would appear not to be the right conditional distribution. Negative binomial could be an alternative.
2. In your plot, it looks like $\\hat y(1\.75\) \= 2\.5$, $\\hat y(3\) \= 4\.8$, and $\\hat y(4\.7\) \= 10$. That is, the conditional distributions are $\\big(Y\\vert X \= 1\.75\\big) \\sim Poisson(2\.5\)$,
$\\big(Y\\vert X \= 3\\big) \\sim Poisson(4\.8\)$,
and $\\big(Y\\vert X \= 4\.7\\big) \\sim Poisson(10\)$. The plots shows sideways plots of those distributions, positioned at the appropriate $x$\-positions.

For that regression curve, you posit that $\\log(\\lambda\_i) \= \\beta\_0 \+ \\beta\_1 x\_i$, equivalent to $\\lambda\_i \= \\exp(\\beta\_0 \+ \\beta\_1x\_i)$, and you find the maximum likelihood estimator for $\\beta\_0$ and $\\beta\_1$, with the curvature explained by the logarithm. (Each $\\lambda\_i$ is the $\\lambda$ parameter of some conditional Poisson distribution (conditional on your predictor variable, $x$).)

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided Poisson regression information:

Question: In a Poisson regression model, the relationship between the predictor variable X and the response variable Y is given by log(λ) = β₀ + β₁X, where λ is the mean of the Poisson distribution. If β₀ = 1.2 and β₁ = 0.5, what is the expected value and variance of Y when X = 3?

A) E[Y] = 7.39, Var(Y) = 7.39
B) E[Y] = 4.48, Var(Y) = 4.48
C) E[Y] = 2.70, Var(Y) = 2.70
D) E[Y] = 5.97, Var(Y) = 5.97

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: In Poisson regression, λ represents both the mean and variance of the Poisson distribution. We can calculate λ as follows:

log(λ) = β₀ + β₁X
log(λ) = 1.2 + 0.5(3) = 2.7

To find λ, we need to exponentiate both sides:
λ = e^2.7 ≈ 7.39

Therefore, E[Y] = Var(Y) = λ ≈ 7.39

This question tests understanding of the Poisson regression model, the relationship between the predictor and response variables, and the equality of mean and variance in a Poisson distribution.

* The app contains at least one .jar file with a universal mac binary containing only an i86 fork, no arm fork
* this app worked with the Oracle JRE (Java 8 Update 311\)
* but once I installed Oracle's JDK 17 for Arm 64 (from the .dmg rather than the tarball), launch failed, whether I launched it from the command line (which would definitely be via the SDK) or from Finder as before.
* In particular, it fails complaining about lack of native arm support.
* presumably some JRE binary, which tolerated/emulated/expected intel, was replaced by one that demanded ARM.

Desired solution:

* Ideally, I'd like to be able to build and debug java apps for both intel and M1 macs, *and* run either type if I downloaded them.
* Failing that, I'd like to be able to have the appropriate SDK installed for my hardware, and still run intel\-only java apps from the JRE.
* I'd settle for a way to uninstall the SDK and get back to the JRE\-only state I had before installing it.

Does anyone know how to accomplish any of these? Oracle's site doesn't even tell me how to uninstall the SDK \- just how to install Java entirely.

Bonus if anyone knows how the app developer, who may not even own a mac, can build his app to work natively on both intel and ARM macs, i.e. populate both parts of the mac universal binary.

\#\#\# Top Answer: The issue here is that you are calling a C library via [jogamp](https://jogamp.org/gluegen/doc/manual/)
The C library provided (I think OpenGL) is Intel only.

Oracle's JDK and JRE are not universal (see [the downloads page](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/downloads/#jdk17-mac)) i.e. they only do one architecture. Similarly the OpenJDKs are not universal.

Thus to run on ARM and Intel you need two different JREs

Pure Java code should run on any operating system (Linux, Solaris, Windows, macOS and others) and on any architecture e.g. Intel, Arm, SPARC. So you only need one jar for all.

The C code could be built universal and your app could be packaged to include both JREs and the launcher (i.e. executable file given in Info.plist) works out from the architecture which JRE to call)

Java 8 worked as it is Intel and so the whole process ran under Rosetta

Question: A Java application that runs on both Intel and ARM-based Macs is experiencing issues after upgrading to an M1 Mac with ARM architecture. The application uses native libraries through JNI. What is the most likely cause of the problem and the best solution?

A) The Java bytecode is incompatible with ARM architecture. Recompile the Java code specifically for ARM.

B) The JDK installed on the M1 Mac is not compatible. Install a universal JDK that supports both Intel and ARM architectures.

C) The native libraries used by the application are compiled only for Intel architecture. Obtain or compile ARM versions of the native libraries and package both versions with the application.

D) The Java Virtual Machine is not optimized for ARM. Switch to a different JVM implementation designed for ARM processors.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The root cause of the issue is that the application is using native libraries (like libgluegen_rt.dylib) that are compiled only for Intel architecture (x86_64). When running on an M1 Mac with ARM architecture, these libraries cannot be loaded, resulting in an UnsatisfiedLinkError.

The best solution is to obtain or compile ARM versions of the native libraries and package both Intel and ARM versions with the application. This allows the application to run natively on both Intel and ARM-based Macs by loading the appropriate version of the library based on the system architecture.

Option A is incorrect because Java bytecode is platform-independent and doesn't need to be recompiled for different architectures.

Option B is incorrect because there isn't a single "universal" JDK that runs natively on both Intel and ARM. Separate JDK installations are typically required for each architecture.

Option D is incorrect because the JVM itself is not the primary issue here. The problem lies with the native libraries, not the Java Virtual Machine implementation.

\#\#\# User: I’m not very clear with the implication of the following sentence in the article titled “The Science of Romance: Why we love” that appeared in Time magazine (Jan.28, 2008\):

> “But if it was that kind of sex that’s the whole reason you took up
>  having sex **in the first place** – the out\-of breath, out\-of\-body,
>  can\-you\-believe\-this–is\-actually\-happening kind of sex – **the rational
>  you had probably taken a powder.”**

My questions:

1. “in the first place” – Does it mean (sex you have) for the first time as a first experience or “as the primary reason (for having sex)?
2. What does “the rational you had probably taken a powder,” mean? 
Which does it mean between “the rational (for having sex) *you had*, had taken a powder (here, 'the rational' is the subject),” or “You *had* the rational *taken* a power (here, 'you' is the subect).”

FYI: Oxford English Dictionary defines ‘take a powder’ as ‘(North American informal) depart quickly, especially in order to avoid a difficult situation, with which I understand ‘take a powder’ is used only in intransitive form.

As a non\-native English speaker, this sentence looks somewhat winding to me. Can you put it in plainer way or in simpler structure? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Breaking it down, *the rational you* means the rational part of your self. *The emotional you* might crave more ice cream, while *the rational you* might resist for good reasons. Use of an article (*the*) with a personal pronoun (*you*) is normally wrong, but it is normal in some circumstances.¹

To *take a powder* is to absent yourself. One literally takes a powder when one excuses one’s self from a social situation to reapply one’s cosmetic powder to one’s face.²

Together, *the rational you had probably taken a powder* means the rational part of yourself had probably absented itself in that situation.

*In the first place* is idiomatic. It means *before now*, as can be discovered in a dictionary of idioms, for example by googling \[[`define in the first place`](http://www.google.com/search?q=define%20in%20the%20first%20place)].

Notes
-----

1\. More at [*Person*](http://books.google.com/books?id=YX2RJhN6mggC&lpg=PA10&ots=q_YFaRQmRE&dq=%22the%20real%20you%22%20definite%20article&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q=%22the%20real%20you%22%20definite%20article&f=false), Anna Siewierska, 2004\.

2\. The phrase does not seem to have a single origin. Besides a visit to the *powder room*, it may also allude to the taking of medical powders, or to stage magic which involved vanishing an object using “magic powder”. For awhile it was popular gang language for leaving town to avoid a confrontation. More at [*Online Etymology Dictionary*](http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=powder).

\#\#\# User: 
> Is the digital root of twin primes product larger than $(3,5\)$ always $8$?

E.g. I just checked the following and it is true was wondering if it is more widely true

$5\\times 7\=35$, digital root $\=3\+5\=8$  

$11\\times 13\=143$, digital root $\=1\+4\+3\=8$  

$17\\times 19\=323$, digital root $\=3\+2\+3\=8$  

$101\\times 103\=10403$, digital root $\=1\+0\+4\+0\+3\=8$

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: One of the basic [properties](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twin_prime#Properties) of twin primes $k\-1$, $k\+1$ is that $k$ must be a multiple of $6$ (except $k\=4$). Set $k\=6t$, and we have $$(k\-1\)(k\+1\)\=(6t\+1\)(6t\-1\)\=36t\-1$$

Hence the product of any pair of twin primes (except $3,5$) will be congruent to $\-1$ modulo $9$. Hence the [digital root](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_root#Congruence_formula) of same will be $8\\equiv \-1\\pmod{9}$.

9.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Consider the following statements about twin primes and their products:

I. The digital root of the product of any pair of twin primes greater than (3,5) is always 8.
II. All twin primes (except 3 and 5) can be expressed in the form 6t-1 and 6t+1, where t is a positive integer.
III. The product of any pair of twin primes (except 3,5) is always congruent to -1 modulo 9.
IV. The digital root of 3 × 5 is also 8.

Which combination of these statements is correct?

A) I, II, and III only
B) II, III, and IV only
C) I, III, and IV only
D) All of the above

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
Statement I is correct. As shown in the documentation, the digital root of the product of any pair of twin primes greater than (3,5) is always 8.

Statement II is correct. This is a basic property of twin primes, where k must be a multiple of 6 (except for the case of 3 and 5).

Statement III is correct. The product of twin primes (6t-1)(6t+1) = 36t²-1, which is always congruent to -1 modulo 9.

Statement IV is incorrect. The product of 3 and 5 is 15, and its digital root is 1+5=6, not 8. This is the exception mentioned in the other statements.

Therefore, only statements I, II, and III are correct, making A the correct answer.

Question: When using the longtable package in LaTeX, which command should be used to ensure that the caption appears only once at the beginning of the table and is listed only once in the list of tables?

A) \endhead
B) \endfirsthead
C) \caption

The correct answer is B) \endfirsthead. This command is specifically used in the longtable environment to define the first table heading, which includes the caption. By using \endfirsthead, you ensure that the caption appears only on the first page of the table and is listed only once in the table of contents.

A) \endhead is incorrect because it defines the heading for all subsequent pages of the table, not just the first page with the caption.

C) \caption is used to create the caption itself, but doesn't control its placement or repetition in a longtable.

D) \listoftables is used to generate the list of tables in the document, but doesn't affect how captions are displayed in individual tables.

Using \endfirsthead allows you to separate the content that should appear only on the first page of the table (including the caption) from the content that should repeat on subsequent pages, solving the problem of repeated captions and multiple entries in the list of tables.

\#\#\# User: Here’s a picture of the door. Notice that you can see light on the handle side...right\-bottom side.

[![space on handle side](https://i.stack.imgur.com/3DHy8.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/3DHy8.jpg)

This is because the top hinge on the left is attached to a piece of wood and that wood is separating a bit from the door frame.

Top hinge (notice the vertical crack in the wood close to left side of the hinge)
[![top hinge](https://i.stack.imgur.com/XFYa2.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/XFYa2.jpg)

Middle hinge
[![middle hinge](https://i.stack.imgur.com/EN50M.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/EN50M.jpg)

Bottom hinge \- Notice the black gap gets narrower as you go down from the top hinge to the bottom hinge.

[![bottom hinge](https://i.stack.imgur.com/uBEbg.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/uBEbg.jpg)

If I hold the handle and lift vertically, the door is easier to close and it doesn’t rub as much against the frame.

Can I just take the screws off and put in a really long screws?

I can potentially bend the top hinge, but I feel like that will only be temporary because of the hinge is separating from the wood (the crack next to the top hinge)

**UPDATE**
I took out a screw from the hinge and it was only 1" long. So, I took a few 3" screws, drove two of them into the top hinge and one in the middle hinge and the door now closes without any binding at all.

[![fixed](https://i.stack.imgur.com/eShwt.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/eShwt.jpg)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It's quite likely that 3\-4" screws will grab hold of the framing behind that top hinge and pull it tight, completely fixing the issue.

It's possible that you may need to loosen the screws in the middle hinge, tighten down the top hinge, then tighten the middle hinge screws.

Also, be on the look out for any nails or screws that hold the casing against the framing. Usually, when a door is installed, the opening is 1/2 \- 1" wider than the door casing so there's plenty of room to get the frame nice and square in the opening. This extra space is filled with shims to hold it in alignment, then it's nailed or screwed through the shims to hold it steady. It's these screws/nails that I'm referring to. They may have been covered with wood putty before the frame was painted, so they may not be very obvious.

If it was nailed into place, the nails may be slowly slipping out of place, but the heads are remaining buried under the putty. As you pull the frame back straight, it may actually pop the nail through. This will be obvious, and you only need to hammer it back in, then use a nail\-set to get it below flush. Some putty \& touch\-up paint and you're done.

If it was screwed into place, the screw could cause the casing to bow as the threads hold the casing in place while your new, longer screws pull the hinge back in line. Use a long straight edge to detect this. The high spot will likely be a screw location \& a magnet should confirm it. You may have to scrape some paint \& putty away, loosen these screws, tighten the ones in the hinges then drive these back home.

Finally, do *not* try to bend the hinge. It won't fix this problem and it will create new ones.

\#\#\# User: I am puzzled with the following problem:

Given $n$ real numbers it is to obtain a Yes/No answer to: "whether it is possible to arrange different points in the Euclidean $\\mathbb{R}^3$ so that every of the given numbers represents a shortest distance which belongs to a distinct pair of points?"

What is an efficient algorithm to solve such problem? If I understand properly, first I have to find $m$ from $n\=\\frac{m(m\+1\)}{2}$ which is the number of such points. But what is the next step? Should I deal with checking the triangle inequality (which seems to be very inefficient) or what?

Thank you in advance!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Let us label the points $x\_0,x\_1,\\dots,x\_m$.
For each pair $(x\_i,x\_j)$ prescribe the a value from your list;
denote it by say $d(x\_i,x\_j)$.
If there are no repititions then all together you have $N\=\[m{\\cdot}(m\+1\)]!$ ways to do this. 

Note that $d(x\_i,x\_j)$ completely determine "$m\\times m$\-matrix of scalar products" 
$$a\_{ij}\=\\tfrac12\\cdot\[d^2(x\_0,x\_i)\+d^2(x\_0,x\_j)\-d^2(x\_i,x\_j)].$$

You need to answer two questions for each of obtained $N$ matrices:

* $(a\_{ij})$ defines a non\-negative quadratic form
* $\\mathop{\\rm rank}(a\_{ij})\\leqslant 3$.

If for one matrix the answers are YES to both then the answer to your question is also YES (and vise versa).

**P.S.** Apparently the statement I used is called *Schoenberg criterion*; thanks to Piotr Hajlasz for pointing this out.

14.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Given a set of n distinct real numbers, which of the following steps is NOT part of the efficient algorithm to determine if it's possible to arrange m points in R³ such that each of the n numbers represents the shortest distance between a distinct pair of points?

A) Calculate m from the equation n = m(m+1)/2
B) Generate all possible N = [m(m+1)]! assignments of the n distances to pairs of points
C) For each assignment, construct an m×m matrix of scalar products
D) Check if the triangle inequality holds for all possible triplets of points

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct algorithm does not involve explicitly checking the triangle inequality for all triplets, which would be inefficient. Instead, it uses the Schoenberg criterion, which involves two key checks for each generated matrix:
1. Whether the matrix defines a non-negative quadratic form
2. Whether the rank of the matrix is ≤ 3

The triangle inequality check (option D) is not part of this efficient algorithm. Options A, B, and C are all steps mentioned or implied in the described approach. Calculating m, generating all possible assignments, and constructing the scalar product matrices are all part of the efficient method outlined in the documentation.

```
0 0 * * * root  [[ -d /var/log/ambari-metrics-collector ]] && find  /var/log/ambari-metrics-collector  -type f -mtime +10 -regex '.*\.log.*[0-9]$' -delete 

0 0 * * * root  [[ -d /var/log/kO ]] && find  /var/log/Ko  -type f -mtime +10 -regex '.*\.log.*[0-9]$' -delete 

0 0 * * * root  [[ -d /var/log/POE ]] && find  /var/log/POE  -type f -mtime +10 -regex '.*\.log.*[0-9]$' -delete  

0 0 * * * root  [[ -d /var/log/REW ]] && find  /var/log/REW  -type f -mtime +10 -regex '.*\.log.*[0-9]$' -delete 

```

is it ok to run all then on the same time? 

dose cron job will run them step by step? or both all them on the same thread?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes, it is perfectly acceptable to have `cron` schedule multiple jobs at the same time.

Computers do *nothing* simultaneously, however, and they will be started in the order present in the `cron` table. However, they will not be run in sequence; they will be started one after the other within a few milliseconds of midnight \-\- simultaneously for all practical purposes.

B) All jobs will start simultaneously and run in parallel threads.

C) The jobs will be started in the order they appear in the cron table, but will run concurrently for practical purposes.

D) Only the first job in the cron table will execute, and the others will be skipped to avoid conflicts.

Explanation: According to the documentation, when multiple cron jobs are scheduled for the same time, they are started in the order they appear in the cron table. The system doesn't wait for one job to complete before starting the next. This approach allows for efficient execution of multiple tasks scheduled for the same time without significant delays between job starts.

\#\#\# User: A few times I've been reminded that an object can have self capacitance and it's just not registering with me how this can be so. I'm sure there's a good explanation. Here's the explanation I am usually given but I'm still not grasping that capacitance can exist when there is only one "electrode": \-

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/gymOb.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/gymOb.png)

The implication of this is that if the outer sphere were massively distant from the inner sphere the formula reduces to: \-

Capacitance \= \\$4\\pi\\epsilon\_0\\times a\\$ because \\$\\dfrac{1}{b} \= 0\\$

**This is used as the argument that the middle object has self\-capacitance**

See [this](http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/electric/capsph.html#c2) as the follow on proof. Maybe I'm being stupid?

---

EDIT to ask a directly related question: \-

I've correctly calculated that a 1mm radius ball will possess a so\-called "self capacitance" of 0\.111pF. If two such balls existed and were placed a million miles away from each other (in an empty universe) would the capacitance between them approximately equal 0\.0555pF i.e. half of 0\.111pF? This "guess" is based on the capacitance of a 1mm ball to an infinite sphere being 0\.111pF and from the infinite sphere to the other ball is another 0\.111pF.

Therefore, with 2 capacitors in series of the same value, the net capacitance is halved. I can't believe that this is true but I'm not really sure.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: To expand on my comment, [this notion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capacitance#Self-capacitance) of self\-capacitance is a theoretical one, much like, say, an ideal operational amplifier is; the latter has infinite \[open\-loop] gain. Here you have a capacitor with infinite distance between plates and the 2nd, reference electrode/sphere also has infinite area. When one comes across such idealizations based on thought experiments, the question to ask is not whether it can exist, but ask why is it a useful notion.

Basically this notion is useful as a first\-order approximation to problems where the distance is finite but large. [For example](https://books.google.com/books?id=fP4wBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA172), [![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/fRfU9.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/fRfU9.png)

"Equation 5\.4" there simply estimates the mutual capacitance of two \[identical] conductors at large distance as one\-half of the self\-capacitance.

Similarly, a first\-order approximation of the capacitance\-to\-ground (which is a mutual capacitance) of a conductor (placed at some significant distance from ground) is the self\-capacitance of the conductor. Ground here is approximated to have infinite area.

Also worth noting here is that mutual capacitance of two finite\-area electrodes differs from their self\-capacitance, even with infinite distance between them.

Also, as you probably discovered already, "self\-capacitance" is also used (e.g. [in transformer contexts](https://books.google.com/books?id=aN0gBQAAQBAJ&pg=SA15-PA3&dq=self-capacitance)) to refer to the mutual, [parasitic capacitance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parasitic_capacitance) of the winding. These two are rather different notions. I don't think the former notion of self\-capacitance helps much with estimating the latter in a transformer.

---

Actually, I can prove the last part even here. From Zangwill, *Modern Electrodynamics* (p. 140\), the capacitance of a two\-conductor capacitor is given by

$$C\= \\frac{C\_{11}C\_{22}\-C^2\_{12}}{C\_{11}\+C\_{22}\+2C\_{12}}$$

Where \\$C\_{ij}\\$ are the [capacitance coefficients](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coefficients_of_potential); in general, this is a symmetric matrix. So if \\$C\_{11} \= C\_{22}\\$ and \\$C\_{12} \= 0\\$ then \\$C\=C\_{11}/2\\$, i.e. the capacitance of the two\-spheres \[at large distance] is half of the self\-capacitance of a sphere.

From [Banerjee](http://www.electrostatics.org/images/ESA_2014_G_Banerjee_et_al.pdf) you can see that the following happens as the distance gets large:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/lmF45.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/lmF45.png)

Those dimensionless capacitance coefficients plotted there are simply:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/kHPEe.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/kHPEe.png)

which means exactly what I wrote above in terms of the non\-dimensionless ones.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: An engineer is designing a system with two identical spherical conductors, each with a radius of 1 mm, placed far apart in space. The self-capacitance of each sphere is calculated to be 0.111 pF. What is the approximate mutual capacitance between these two spheres when they are placed at a very large distance from each other?

A) 0.111 pF
B) 0.0555 pF
C) 0.222 pF
D) 0.0278 pF

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B (0.0555 pF). This problem relates to the concept of self-capacitance and mutual capacitance of conductors at large distances.

A) 0.111 pF is incorrect. This is the self-capacitance of each individual sphere, not the mutual capacitance between them.

B) 0.0555 pF is correct. As explained in the documentation, for two identical conductors at a large distance, the mutual capacitance can be approximated as one-half of the self-capacitance. Since each sphere has a self-capacitance of 0.111 pF, the mutual capacitance would be approximately 0.111 pF / 2 = 0.0555 pF.

C) 0.222 pF is incorrect. This would be the sum of the self-capacitances, not the mutual capacitance.

D) 0.0278 pF is incorrect. This would be one-quarter of the self-capacitance, which is not the correct relationship for mutual capacitance at large distances.

The answer can be further verified by the formula provided in the documentation: C = (C11*C22 - C12^2) / (C11 + C22 + 2C12). When the distance is very large, C12 approaches 0, and C11 = C22 (self-capacitance of each sphere). This reduces to C = C11/2, which is exactly what we calculated.

> A good way of figuring out what a function **is** doing **is** to type

\#\#\# Top Answer: It can, although the two instances in your example are not exactly of the same type. The first *is* is a form of the function verb *be*, (it forms the present progressive of *do*), and the second is a form of the lexical verb *be* (here a verb in its own right).

Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the grammatical function of the two instances of "is" in the sentence: "A good way of figuring out what a function is doing is to type it without the parentheses."?

A) Both instances of "is" are auxiliary verbs.
B) The first "is" is an auxiliary verb, while the second "is" is a main verb.
C) The first "is" is a main verb, while the second "is" is an auxiliary verb.
D) Both instances of "is" are main verbs.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The first "is" in the sentence is part of the present progressive tense "is doing," where it functions as an auxiliary verb helping to form the progressive aspect of the main verb "doing." The second "is" functions as a main verb (also called a lexical verb) in its own right, linking the subject "A good way of figuring out what a function is doing" to the complement "to type it without the parentheses." This question tests the ability to distinguish between different grammatical functions of the same word within a single sentence.

\#\#\# User: I have a RL circuit 

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/cJYnu.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/cJYnu.jpg)

I have to find the current in the mash I L(t) so the mesh current but the initial I L(0\) \= I initial \= 3 mAH, now I have the the I(t) when I assumed that t\=0 which is:

```
I(t) = Vs/R (1 - e^((-R/L)*t)))

```

Then I have done everything again with the assumption that I L(0\) \= I ini
and then I have got this equation:

```
I L(t) = Vs/R + (I ini - Vs/R) * e ^ ((-R/L) * T)

```

And then I have the given values: Vs\=10V, R\=1kOHM, L\=1mH and I ini \= 3mA

Then I substitute everything but the function is so weird (I also should get the I L(0\) \= 3mAH, but I dont) and I cannot even procede to do the Euler's explicit interation to plot the results, can anyone tell me if my equation is wrong, if it is can someone explain why and how can I fix it in order to work?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I wish you'd exposed more details of how you walked through your process. But at least you show some work. Rather than point to an error, I'd rather simply walk through the process as I'd see it, instead.

Schematic:

![schematic](https://i.stack.imgur.com/FbgKlm.png)

[simulate this circuit](/plugins/schematics?image=http%3a%2f%2fi.stack.imgur.com%2fFbgKlm.png) – Schematic created using [CircuitLab](https://www.circuitlab.com/)

Nodal analysis provides:

$$\\begin{align\*}
\\frac{V\_X}{R\_1}\+\\frac{1}{L\_1}\\int V\_X\\:\\text{d}t\&\= \\frac{V\_S}{R\_1}
\\end{align\*}$$

Taking the derivative, I get:

$$\\begin{align\*}
\\frac{\\text{d} V\_X}{R\_1\\:\\text{d}t}\+\\frac{V\_X}{L\_1}\&\= 0\\\\\\\\
\\frac{\\text{d} V\_X}{\\text{d}t}\&\= \-\\frac{R\_1\\:V\_X}{L\_1}\\\\\\\\
\\frac{\\text{d} V\_X}{V\_X}\&\= \-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:\\text{d}t\\\\\\\\
\\int \\frac{\\text{d} V\_X}{V\_X}\&\= \\int\-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:\\text{d}t\\\\\\\\
\\operatorname{ln}\\left(V\_X\\right)\&\= \-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:t\+C\_0\\\\\\\\
V\_X \&\= A\_0\\:e^{\-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:t}
\\end{align\*}$$

The initial conditions are that \\$V\_{X\_{t\=0}}\=A\_0\=V\_S\-I\_0\\cdot R\_1\\$. So, the above becomes:

$$\\begin{align\*}
V\_X \&\= \\left(V\_S\-I\_0\\cdot R\_1\\right)\\:e^{\-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:t}
\\end{align\*}$$

You know that the current must always be \\$I\_X\=\\frac{V\_S\-V\_X}{R\_1}\\$, so:

$$\\begin{align\*}
I\_X \&\= \\frac{V\_S\-\\left(V\_S\-I\_0\\cdot R\_1\\right)\\:e^{\-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:t}}{R\_1}\\\\\\\\
\&\=\\frac{V\_S}{R\_1}\\cdot\\left(1\-e^{\-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:t}\\right)\+I\_0\\cdot e^{\-\\frac{R\_1}{L\_1}\\:t}
\\end{align\*}$$

It is handy to set \\$\\tau\=\\frac{L\_1}{R\_1}\\$. Then:

$$\\begin{align\*}
I\_X\&\=\\frac{V\_S}{R\_1}\\cdot\\left(1\-e^{\-\\frac{t}{\\tau}}\\right)\+I\_0\\cdot e^{\-\\frac{t}{\\tau}}
\\end{align\*}$$

If you figure \\$\\tau\=1\\:\\mu\\text{s}\\$, \\$I\_0\=3\\:\\text{mA}\\$, \\$V\_S\=10\\:\\text{V}\\$, \\$R\_1\=1\\:\\text{k}\\Omega\\$, and plug in \\$t\=0\\$ you will find \\$I\_{X\_{t\=0}}\=3\\:\\text{mA}\\$ (Also, \\$I\_{X\_{t\=1\\:\\mu\\text{s}}}\\approx 7\.4\\:\\text{mA}\\$ and \\$I\_{X\_{t\=2\\:\\mu\\text{s}}}\\approx 9\.1\\:\\text{mA}\\$, etc.)

Here's a multi-part exam question based on the RL circuit analysis:

Question: Consider the RL circuit described in the documentation. Given Vs=10V, R=1kΩ, L=1mH, and initial current I0=3mA, which of the following statements is correct?

A) The time constant τ of the circuit is 1ms.

B) The current in the circuit at t=0 is 10mA.

C) The steady-state current (as t approaches infinity) will be 13mA.

D) The equation for the current I(t) is:
I(t) = 10*(1-e^(-1000t)) + 0.003*e^(-1000t) [A]

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A) is incorrect because τ = L/R = 1mH / 1kΩ = 1µs, not 1ms.
B) is incorrect because the initial current I(0) is given as 3mA.
C) is incorrect because the steady-state current will be Vs/R = 10V/1kΩ = 10mA.
D) is correct. It matches the derived equation I(t) = (Vs/R)*(1-e^(-t/τ)) + I0*e^(-t/τ), with the values properly substituted: Vs/R = 10mA, τ = 1µs = 10^-6 s, so -1/τ = -10^6 = -1000000, and I0 = 3mA = 0.003A.

This question tests understanding of RL circuit behavior, time constants, steady-state conditions, and the ability to recognize the correct mathematical representation of the current.

\#\#\# User: I recently had my house power washed and two out of four outside GFCI outlets in weather resistant enclosures leaked in some water/cleaning solution and caught fire and burned.

An electrician ohmed the circuit back to the panel and determined the wires where fine. The receptacles were replaced with new weather proof GFCI outlets.

I bought a Klein RT310 AFCI/GFCI Outlet Tester to test the rest of my circuits. The new Eaton GFCI receptacles trip properly and the tester shows them as both Open Neutral and Open Ground when tripped.

I have two of the older type of GFCI outlets that also trip properly, but the Klein RT310 indicates open Hot when tripped on these older GFCI outlets.

Why would the newer GFCIs indicate open Neutral/Open Ground, but the older GFCIs indicate Open Hot when tripped?

Are the older GFCIs that indicate Open Hot defective even though they trip when tested? Should they be replaced also?

Video here:
[https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1k1l0qu8bEbDwyDmCfKZYSBQaWGDgRRqI?usp\=sharing](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1k1l0qu8bEbDwyDmCfKZYSBQaWGDgRRqI?usp=sharing)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Those things are even worse than the simple "Magic 8\-ball testers"
-------------------------------------------------------------------

With 3\-lamp testers, you can ignore the extremely unhelpful and highly misleading text on the label, and let the 3 lights talk to you directly.

Those so\-called "smart" testers hide the useful lights behind a computer, and present *only* the unhelpful and highly misleading interpretation.

The problem is, all these testers are tuned for searching new construction for *assembly errors*. They are unintended for chasing problems which have developed in old wiring, *because those are not assembly errors*. So they tend to give bad data that sends you on a wild goose chase.

"open hot" tells you there's no power at all here.
--------------------------------------------------

And that is working as intended. The GFCI is supposed to disconnect both hot and neutral wires when it trips. We can't be sure about neutral, but there's no doubt it has disconnected the hot.

The stupid label gives that condition a name, "Open Hot", but *good grief*. It means all lights are off. It'll indicate "open hot" while it's in your pocket!

If you suspect the GFCI has not interrupted neutral, you can test for that with an ohmmeter I suppose. I would indeed replace a GFCI that only interrupts hot. Neutral can be hot too, under certain circumstances.

19.answer:

Question: An electrician is testing GFCI outlets with a Klein RT310 AFCI/GFCI Outlet Tester. When tripped, newer GFCI outlets show "Open Neutral and Open Ground," while older GFCI outlets show "Open Hot." What is the most likely explanation for this difference?

A) The older GFCI outlets are defective and need to be replaced immediately.
B) The Klein RT310 tester is malfunctioning and giving inaccurate readings.
C) The newer GFCI outlets use a different tripping mechanism than the older ones.
D) The tester's interpretation is misleading, and "Open Hot" actually indicates that the GFCI is functioning correctly by disconnecting both hot and neutral.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. The documentation explains that these "smart" testers can be misleading in their interpretations. When a GFCI trips, it should disconnect both hot and neutral wires. The "Open Hot" reading on older GFCIs actually indicates that there's no power at all, which is the intended function. The tester's interpretation is overly simplistic and designed for new construction assembly errors, not for diagnosing issues in existing wiring. The difference in readings between older and newer GFCIs is likely due to changes in how the tester interprets the lack of power, rather than a fundamental difference in how the GFCIs function. Therefore, the "Open Hot" reading on older GFCIs does not necessarily indicate a defect, but rather that the GFCI is working as intended by cutting off power completely when tripped.

\#\#\# Top Answer: For a \*nix command line it makes the most sense and is the most readable, in my opinion, to put it in a code block and use a `\` line continuation to break it into readable length lines. Horizontal scrolling on these long single lines make them very difficult (for me) to grasp when you can't see the whole thing.

```
magick convert *.png -trim -background none \
    -resize 300x300 -gravity center \
    -extent 300x300 out/processed.png

```

This can even be pasted.

Question: Which of the following is considered the most readable and practical way to present a long Unix command line in documentation or online forums?

A) Using inline backticks:
`magick convert *.png -trim -background none -resize 300x300 -gravity center -extent 300x300 out/processed.png`

B) Using a single-line code block:
```

```

C) Using a multi-line code block with line continuation:
```
magick convert *.png -trim -background none \

```

D) Using hashtags to highlight the command:
#magick convert *.png -trim -background none -resize 300x300 -gravity center -extent 300x300 out/processed.png#

Explanation: Option C is considered the most readable and practical way to present a long Unix command line. It uses a code block, which is appropriate for command-line instructions, and employs line continuation with the backslash (\) character. This approach breaks the command into multiple lines of readable length, eliminating the need for horizontal scrolling and making it easier to understand the different parts of the command. Additionally, this format can be easily copied and pasted into a terminal. Option A (inline backticks) is better suited for short commands within text. Option B (single-line code block) can require horizontal scrolling, making it difficult to read. Option D (hashtags) is not a standard way to format command-line instructions and may not be recognized by many readers or syntax highlighters.

\#\#\# User: I have to generate random numbers for my algorithm based on probability distributions. I want a distribution which has heavy tails and is unskewed, which can produce numbers far away from location parameter. There should be a parameter to control the tail heaviness (e.g., like levy distribution where alpha determines tail heaviness).

I have identified the t\-distribution (for smaller degrees of freedom) and the laplace distribution as two possibilities. 

* Are there any reasons to prefer t or laplace for my purpose?
* Apart from t\-distribution and laplace distribution, is there any distribution except cauchy or levy that would be useful for my purpose?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Heavy\-tail Lambert W x F distributions](http://arxiv.org/abs/1010.2265) seem to be what you are looking for (disclaimer: I am the author). They arise from a parametric, non\-linear transformation of a random variable (RV) $X \\sim F$, to a heavy\-tailed version $Y \\sim \\text{Lambert W} \\times F$. For $F$ being Gaussian they reduce to Tukey's $h$ distribution. 

They have one parameter $\\delta \\geq 0$ that regulates the degree of tail heaviness (you can also choose different left and right heavy tails). In its most basic form it transforms a standard Normal $U \\sim \\mathcal{N}(0,1\)$ to a Lambert W $\\times$ Gaussian $Z$ by
$$
Z \= U \\exp\\left(\\frac{\\delta}{2} U^2\\right)
$$

If $\\delta \> 0$ $Z$ has heavier tails than $U$; for $\\delta \= 0$ $Z$ falls back to your initial RV $U$. 

If you don't want to use the Gaussian distribution as your baseline, you can just create other Lambert W versions of your favorite distributions, e.g. t, uniform, gamma, exponential, beta, ... However, for the purpose of heavy\-tails the Gaussian seems to be the obvious baseline reference.

Since this heavy\-tail generation is based on transformations of RVs/data rather than a manipulation of cdfs or pdfs, it is very convenient to implement: just use your code to simulate any standard RV, add one line that transforms it, and then you have a random sample from the heavy\-tail version of your initial RV.

In R this becomes (using the [LambertW](http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/LambertW/index.html) package)

```
library(LambertW)
set.seed(1)
zz = rLambertW(n=1000, distname = "normal", beta = c(0,1), delta = 0.5)
normfit(zz)

```

You can also fit the best model to the data using a maximum likelihood estimator (MLE)

```
model = MLE_LambertW(zz, distname = "normal", type = "h")
summary(model)
plot(model)

```

While the t-distribution and Laplace distribution (options A and B) can have heavy tails, they don't offer the same level of flexibility and customization as the Lambert W x F distribution. The Cauchy distribution (option D) does have heavy tails but doesn't provide a straightforward parameter for controlling tail heaviness like the Lambert W x F distribution does.

\#\#\# User: I have a USB drive with some archive data on it that I'd like to access from a Mac running Snow Leopard. However, I want to ensure that the data on the drive is preserved and no modifications are made to the drive. The drive is FAT32 formatted and does not have a write\-protect switch on it. How can I make the drive read\-only or otherwise write\-protect it by the OS so that I can ensure nothing is modified on the drive?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **Option 1: Mount drive read\-only**

You can mount the USB drive read\-only by using Diskutil.

* First, insert/mount the drive once, run `diskutil list` from Terminal.app and take note of the device representing the drive (should be something like `/dev/diskN` with N being any number).
* Eject the disk by running `diskutil unmountDisk /dev/diskN` replacing N by the number noted in the first step
* Mount the disk read\-only by running `diskutil mountDisk readOnly /dev/diskN`

This of course requires that you actively run these commands every time you want to use the archive stick. For an automated solution, have a look at [MarcoPolo](http://www.symonds.id.au/marcopolo/) or write a launchd command (see e.g. [here](http://www.macresearch.org/tutorial_backups_with_launchd) for inspiration).

**Option 2: Use access control on the drive**

Does the drive really need to be formatted in FAT32 or do you only access it from a Mac OSX system anyway? In the later case, you can save the drive content on another drive, reformat it as a Mac OSX drive, move/copy the content back and take away any write rights from anybody.

Question: In an n-dimensional optimization problem using hill climbing, you need to generate a random direction vector. Which of the following methods correctly generates a uniformly distributed random direction in n-dimensional space?

A) Generate n random numbers between -1 and 1, then normalize the resulting vector.

B) Generate n random numbers from a standard normal distribution (mean 0, variance 1), then normalize the resulting vector.

C) Generate n random numbers between 0 and 1, then apply the inverse cumulative distribution function of the normal distribution to each, and finally normalize the resulting vector.

D) Generate n-1 random angles between 0 and 2π, use these to compute n Cartesian coordinates on the unit hypersphere, then normalize the resulting vector.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option B is the correct method for generating a uniformly distributed random direction in n-dimensional space. This approach, known as the Gaussian method, involves generating n independent random numbers from a standard normal distribution and then normalizing the resulting vector.

A is incorrect because using uniform random numbers between -1 and 1 will not result in a uniform distribution on the hypersphere surface when normalized.

C is unnecessarily complicated and does not provide the correct distribution.

D describes the hyperspherical coordinate method, which is valid but more complex and computationally expensive than the Gaussian method, especially for high dimensions.

The Gaussian method (B) is simple, efficient, and produces the desired uniform distribution on the hypersphere surface, making it ideal for generating random directions in hill climbing optimization.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In literature and idiomatic expressions, what term is often used to describe a seemingly strong character's singular weakness that can lead to their downfall, similar to how a silver bullet affects a werewolf?

A) Perfect storm
B) Achilles heel
C) Silver lining
D) Pandora's box

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: An "Achilles heel" refers to a weakness or vulnerable point in an otherwise strong or powerful entity. This term originates from Greek mythology, where the hero Achilles was invulnerable except for his heel. In modern usage, it describes a fatal flaw or weakness that can lead to one's downfall, despite overall strength or success. This matches the description in the question of a precise vulnerability that can bring about destruction, similar to how a silver bullet affects a werewolf.

"Perfect storm" (A) refers to a rare combination of events that worsen a situation dramatically, but doesn't specifically relate to a singular weakness.

"Silver lining" (C) means a positive aspect in a negative situation, which is not relevant to the concept of a fatal flaw.

"Pandora's box" (D) refers to a source of extensive troubles released into the world, which doesn't fit the idea of a specific weakness in an otherwise strong entity.

\#\#\# User: Searching Google for the history of the slang term "the bomb" (as in "That song is the bomb") yields a number of results in 40s/50s jazz glossaries, but they tend to at best give an artificial example of usage, nothing about the actual history behind the usage. Here's one such glossary (there are numerous others): [Jazz Slang](http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=1404).

I'm wondering if this is based on some actual history of the term, or if a bunch of "jazz glossaries" are just copying from each other, especially since there are some other comprehensive glossaries that do not include the term. I also very much thought the term was more modern than the Jazz Era, but I could be falling for the recency fallacy there. Then again, considering that the atomic bomb was dropped in the 40's it's feasible that the term originated in the Jazz scene.

The oldest reference I could find of this usage is from 1973 [here](http://books.google.com/books?id=4YfsEgHLjboC&pg=PA220&lpg=PA220&dq=%22the%20bomb%22%20slang&source=bl&ots=7JXDI6l14c&sig=6PAMrKc-8yq8j7YxvkcyqXKIEPg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_pT6Uu3aI5W0sQTpqoGgDA&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=%22the%20bomb%22%20slang&f=false), but I don't have access to the OED, so I'm not sure if there's an older reference in there. Several regular dictionaries include this meaning, but either don't list any origin or only say "Origin: US".

I found an article on dictionary.com, [Lexical Investigations: Bomb](http://blog.dictionary.com/bomb/), which mostly focuses on a different related terms (just "bomb" not "the bomb"), but in passing says "the bomb" originated in Great Britain and rubbed off on Americans in the 90's. But it doesn't give any citations or references to support that. 

Related question about the term "cool", which did originate in the Jazz scene: [Where did the slang usages of "cool" come from?](https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/43063/where-did-the-slang-usages-of-cool-come-from)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Summary
-------

I can't find any evidence to suggest this is a jazz term, and the earliest example I found is from 1995\. The alternative *da bomb* dates from at least 1994\.

There's no entry in a number of slang dictionaries (*A Jazz Lexicon*, *A Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English*, *Shorter Slang Dictionary*, *The Slang and Jargon of Drugs and Drink*, *A Dictionary of Cliches*, *American Heritage Dictionary of Idioms*, *British English A to Zed*). This suggests it's a recent term.

'50s claims
-----------

Like your linked [Jazz Slang](http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=1404#.Uvym6fmSzl8), [it's](http://www.grooveb3.com/Blog/Jazz_Dictionary.php) [often](http://www.teenjazz.com/music-news-history/jazz-lingo-slang.html) [claimed](http://dazzlingal.com/2011/11/14/slang-from-the-20s-to-the-50s/) to be 1950s or jazz slang but there's no evidence for it. This list of [50's Slang](http://wwwinfoworld.com/50sslang.htm) includes:

> **The Bomb** \-\-\- Very cool.
> 
> 
> *The Crusader's new disc, "Louisiana Hot Sauce" is "the bomb."*

The list is undated but was first archived in [2002](http://web.archive.org/web/20020814021621/http://www.wwwinfoworld.com/50sslang.htm). Further, The Crusaders' released *Louisiana Hot Sauce* in [1996](http://www.allmusic.com/album/louisiana-hot-sauce-mw0000243002). The others all seem to be copies of this (or another).

*OED*
-----

Although not exactly the same, the closest thing in the *OED* is:

> **1e.** A success (esp. in entertainment); also *U.S*., a failure. So phr. **like a bomb** and varr., with great speed; with considerable effectiveness or success. *colloq.*

Here's the first and a couple of other quotations:

> 1954 Amer. Speech 29 99 Like a bomb,..very fast.
> 
> 
> 1961 New Yorker 28 Oct. 43/2 What had once been called a failure became a ‘bomb’.
> 
> 
> 1963 The Beatles 5 Once, Paul McCartney and I played Reading as the Nurk Twins. Went down a bomb, I recall.

All the quotations are "a bomb" not "the bomb" and are quite different.

Lexical Investigations
----------------------

The only relevant quotation from your linked [Lexical Investigations: Bomb](http://blog.dictionary.com/bomb/) is fairly recent:

> “Your magazine is the bomb! I really like the comics and when you make fun of that Spears girl.”
> 
> 
> —[Spin](http://books.google.com/books?id=xfEjLof28w8C&pg=PA28&dq=bomb%20intitle:Spin%20-atomic&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Ri23Ubv3J4moyAHP3IGQBw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwADge#v=onepage&q=bomb%20intitle:Spin%20-atomic&f=false), September 2002

Google Groups
-------------

The earliest "is the bomb" I found in Google Groups (there may be earlier, but Google recently redesigned Groups and crippled the search) is this exchange from [August 1996](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!search/%22that$20*$20is$20the$20bomb%22/alt.music.beck/zMFj7bXcuBM/UMcSL7-BnyEJ):

> On 21 Aug 1996, Cheezmelt wrote:
> 
> 
> 
> > If I wrote a song, it'd be called " Beck is the Bomb"
> 
> 
> And it would be the Bomb.
> 
> 
> Or maybe it would be called "Loopity loo and your mom too"
> 
> 
> I haven't decided
> 
> 
> Geez don't you kids know anything?
> 
> 
> whenever something is the bomb,
> 
> 
> and you specify that it is THE bomb,
> 
> 
> you must follow it with the phrase, YO.
> 
> 
> for example, "that shit was the bomb, yo!"
> 
> 
> as opposed to:
> 
> 
> when something is merely bomb, and there
> 
> 
> is no the, then you would say something like
> 
> 
> "That's some bomb acid!"
> 
> 
> stay in school!

There's nothing before 1996, and quite a few after and into the 2000s and this decade.

Subzin movie subtitles
----------------------

The earliest I found in film subtitles is the [1995](http://www.subzin.com/search.php?title=Clockers&imdb=&q=the%20bomb&search_sort=Popularity&genre=-1&type=All) Spike Lee film *Clockers* which uses it twice:

> 00:04:35 \# Blue collar comes to bourgeois  
> 
> 00:04:37 \# Depressed in your chest... \#  
> 
> 00:04:39 \- Chuck D is the bomb, boy. \- What?  
> 
> 00:04:41 Get the fuck outta here. Chuck D ain't shit.  
> 
> 00:04:44 That nigger Chuck D is assed out, and the rest of Public Enemy.

And:

> 01:12:18 \- One drink? Wasn't drunk? \- Nope.  
> 
> 01:12:21 \- He was rude. \- (Bartender) Yeah.  
> 
> 01:12:26 'Ooh! I'm just gettin' warmed up. But it's The Bomb.'  
> 
> 01:12:30 Was he with anybody?  
> 
> 01:12:33 He came in alone. Might've had a conversation.

The film was released in September 1995 and based on a 1992 book by Richard Price, although the book [doesn't appear to use the phrase](http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=M2E0MDvs2PIC&pg=PA292&dq=intitle:clockers%20%20bomb&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZKT8Ur2lGMas4ASK6oDABw&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%20bomb&f=false).

"Da bomb"
---------

There's even more and earlier Google Groups results for the variant *da bomb*, such as this from soc.culture.filipino in [December 1994](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!search/%22da$20bomb%22%7Csort:date/soc.culture.filipino/EseNdO_SosU/9JItMvwUz3wJ) ("SCF at REDj is DA BOMB...."):

> > Actually, "DA BOMB" is part of the continuous urban parlance that Filipino teenagers tend to borrow from African American teenagers. "DA BOMB" is a comprable adjective to such words used in the past, like "swell," "groovy," "cool," "radical," "gnarly," "awesome," "def," and "hype."
> > 
> > 
> > Elson  
> > 
> > Urban Lingust
> 
> 
> Dr. Vicente Rafael, a Filipino\-American and an associate professor at UCSD's communications department describes this phenomenon as "downward assimilation"; Filipino\-American teenagers borrow the language, clothes, and mannerisms from pop black culture because they perceive it to be a more sexual, more agressive (as in violent) culture, characteristics which they perceive to be wanting in their own native culture.

A few days later in the same group ("\*\*\* DA BOMB \*\*\*"):

> OKay ppl... I haven't been posting as on SCF due to the fact I'm forming a new IRC channel w/ MinMei aka NeuSpeed. This new channel will hopefully be Da BOMB.... N E Wayz... I see that ppl responded to the comment I made at REDj's party...
> 
> 
> The Party Was Da BOMB (the best in the West)... and it seems that ppl around here (Elson, Rhett...) no names will be mention seems to put that title to me... Okay Elson... I'll go on an airplane and say to the pilot this "Da BOMB"!!!! \=) NE Wayz.... look out for the new channel...

There's an earlier use in comp.sys.mac.apps from [July 1994](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!search/%22da$20bomb%22%7Csort:date/comp.sys.mac.apps/ZYntPFhm_t4/p4gHV1biFnQJ). The post discusses Apple computer crashes ("Has anyone else had problems with Appleshare causing a system bomb on startup?") but the subject seems to be a passing reference to the phrase:

> Appleshare and "da BOMB"

\#\#\# User: I'm designing a makeshift mouse clicker using an RP2040 microcontroller. To keep this small and concise, I'm using a USB Type\-A Male connector on the PCB to connect to the PC directly. From what I read, the RP2040 uses USB Full Speed (USB\-FS). I have a few questions regarding the routing of the USB signal.

1. Firstly, my PCB assembly manufacturer does not have a USB2\.0 male connector in stock and only has USB3\.0 connector. **Can I use that and leave the other pins unconnected?**
2. The DP and DM pins of the RP2040 are not aligned to the USB connector, so I have to cross them. What is the best way to do this?

a. **Option 1 (Through the termination resistor) \- Track length difference \= \-33mil**
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/l0h4l.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/l0h4l.jpg)

b. **Option 2 (Through vias) \- Track length difference \= 0mil**
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/FthOr.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/FthOr.jpg)
3. **How do I calculate what is the necessary trace width and length required for the signal?** I plan to use the the standard 1\.6mm FR4 board.
4. I understand there needs to be a ground pour under signals. In the case of option B, **do I put a ground pour on top and the bottom of the signals?**

Any further suggestions on the routing will be much appreciated. Thank you in advance.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Why would you ever *not* use a fuse? It's basic protection.

Sometimes a tungsten filament bulb or several in parallel (in series with the fuse) can help during early testing. It has relatively low resistance when the filament is cold, and it limits current when the filament is hot.

29.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: When designing a USB device using an RP2040 microcontroller, which approach is recommended for routing the differential pair (D+ and D-) signals on the PCB?

A) Route the signals with unequal lengths, crossing through the termination resistors
B) Route the signals with equal lengths, using vias to cross them
C) Route the signals with the widest possible trace width to minimize impedance
D) Route the signals without any ground pour underneath for reduced capacitance

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option B is the correct answer because it maintains equal length traces for the differential pair, which is crucial for USB signal integrity. Using vias to cross the signals allows for maintaining this equal length while still routing to the correct pins on the connector.

Option A is incorrect because unequal length traces can cause signal skew and degrade performance.

Option C is incorrect because USB signals require controlled impedance, typically around 90 ohms differential. Widest possible traces would likely not achieve this.

Option D is incorrect because a ground pour under high-speed signals like USB is generally recommended for maintaining controlled impedance and reducing EMI.

The question tests understanding of USB signal routing best practices, particularly the importance of length matching and controlled impedance for differential pairs.

\#\#\# User: In Shivam Sarodia's answer to [Escape Velocity question](https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/53411/escape-velocity-question) he states:

"For a rocket launched exactly at escape velocity"

This seems to be a repeated, and unclear way of discussing the matter of escape velocity since it doesn't say when or how long escape velocity is occurring for the rocket.

1. Does the escape velocity only need to occur momentarily and then thrust can be removed ( so therefore an initial velocity to a ballistic trajectory)
2. Or does the velocity need to be maintained for some period of time before thrust is cut?
3. Or are there other details/conditions that need to be considered?

I suspect 1\. above is the correct interpretation, and that if I write the equations of motion I can demonstrate that's so in simulation. But it seems so many text books and discussions on the subject do not really make it clear the circumstances surrounding the definition of escape velocity. Even Feynman's lectures are not clear on this point \- but they do have other interesting aspects.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes, it's an initial velocity in a ballistic trajectory in a vacuum. The escape velocity is derived using conservation of energy at two different points in time, as $\\frac {1}{2} mv\_0^2\-\\frac {G M m}{r\_0}\>0$. $v\_0$ means initial velocity.

In practice you haveto worry about the atmosphere and all that.

30.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A rocket is launched from the surface of a planet with no atmosphere. Which of the following statements about escape velocity is correct?

A) The rocket must maintain escape velocity constantly throughout its entire journey to escape the planet's gravitational field.

B) The rocket only needs to achieve escape velocity for a brief moment at launch, after which it can cut its engines and follow a ballistic trajectory to escape.

C) Escape velocity is the minimum speed needed to reach a specific altitude above the planet's surface, not to escape its gravitational field entirely.

D) The rocket must exceed escape velocity and maintain a higher speed to successfully escape the planet's gravitational field.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Escape velocity is an initial velocity in a ballistic trajectory in a vacuum. It is derived using conservation of energy, comparing the initial kinetic energy to the gravitational potential energy. Once a body achieves escape velocity, it has enough kinetic energy to overcome the planet's gravitational potential energy without any additional thrust. Therefore, a rocket only needs to reach escape velocity momentarily at launch, after which it can cut its engines and still escape the planet's gravitational field. Options A, C, and D are incorrect as they misrepresent the concept of escape velocity or add unnecessary conditions.
