Question: According to current electrical codes, what is required for 240-volt residential appliances that need a neutral connection?

A) A 3-prong outlet with hot, neutral, and ground wires combined
B) A 4-prong outlet with two hot wires, a neutral, and a ground wire
C) A 3-prong outlet with two hot wires and a neutral, grounding through the neutral
D) A 5-prong outlet with two hot wires, neutral, ground, and a surge protector wire

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The current electrical code requires that 240-volt residential appliances needing a neutral connection must have a separate, properly sized ground wire in addition to the neutral. This necessitates a 4-prong configuration with two hot wires, a neutral wire, and a separate ground wire. Option A is incorrect as it combines neutral and ground, which is against code. Option C is outdated and unsafe, as it relies on grounding through the neutral. Option D adds an unnecessary fifth prong that is not standard or required by code.

\#\#\# User: I'd like to swap the `Fn` and `Ctrl` keys on my ThinkPad W500 (like many others! See: [How can I switch the function and control keys on my laptop?](https://superuser.com/questions/35228/how-can-i-switch-the-function-and-control-keys-on-my-laptop) and [Intercepting the Fn key on laptops](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/514781/intercepting-the-fn-key-on-laptops))

1. Numerous folks indicate that Windows doesn't register the `Fn` key as a keypress but using [Mihov ASCII Master 2\.0](http://www.mihov.com/eng/am.html), that gives the ASCII value of a keypress, I see the Fn key returning FF (perhaps FF in this case means 'not registered'). I also see that keys like `Ctrl` register with one ASCII code when pressed alone and another when pressed in combo with another key. `Fn` will only register when pressed alone, so Windows definitely isn't seeing the combo. This took a solution like AutoHotKey off the table.
2. I ran [KeyTweak](http://webpages.charter.net/krumsick/) (which shows you the hardware scan codes of a keypress and the `Fn` key registerd as 57443\). Using this program I remapped `Fn` to the `Ctrl` key; this worked perfectly. However, I suspect that because of the issue in \#1, the combo of, for example, `Fn` \+ `C` did *not* execute a copy.

Short of retraining my pinky I'm actually considering removing the keyboard and resoldering the connections to swap those keys.

I'd love to get some input as to the root technical issue(s) and possible solutions here.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Apparently the FN key is not handled by the Windows keyboard driver, but rather by drivers developed by Lenovo. Hence remapping of the FN key is impossible by any Windows utility that switches keys, because the Fn key doesn't generate any scan\-codes.

Apparently Lenovo is currently considering a modification to the BIOS that will make this possible. See this article: ["Switch Mode for Fn/Ctrl Keys"](http://blog.lenovo.com/design/switch-mode-for-fn-ctrl-keys-follow-up).

In conclusion you should (1\) regard your BIOS to see if such an option already exists, and if not (2\) check the Lenovo site for BIOS upgrades from time to time (just note that BIOS upgrades need to be done very very carefully, since a mistake means bricking your computer).

In the meantime, you can use this solution (just joking):

![image](https://i.stack.imgur.com/mDOBO.jpg)

\#\#\# User: I have a JED file from a GAL 16V8 as an example.
Is there a tool to decode this into a schematic of gates and registers?

Coders: Is this a hard "interface" program to write to have ispLever or some other CAD create an schematic output from a jed file as input?

---

Disappointed "are you stealing code?" is an automatic goto for anyone wanting a decompiler.
I have been writing in OPAL for quite a while, while they were still shipping the demo\-disc bundle kit I got from them in the mail in '93\.
Limited availability, and I got one.
Thank you National Semiconductor.

But schematic tools were not at my finger tips then, and tools shareware or licenced have advanced in the market since 1993\.

My computers have died many times since then, and sometimes only my project remains without the files.
I don't lock my chips unless they are going into the wild.
So I can read them anytime I want.
Copy them anytime I want.

Having spent far\-to\-long yesterday reverse\-engineering a JEDEC file I created looking for and hand\-correcting errors, it would be nice if I could load it into a translator and see if my edits look like what I think they should be.

30 years was quite a while ago, and I haven't GAL'd in years.
I get rusty in what I knew then. It was all clearer 30 years ago.
Where are my notes???

It would be nice to read my old chips, and see what I was thinking back then, or take a few out of the pile and see what they were supposed to represent.

If I have to hand\-draw and decipher the maps, I don't have that kind of time anymore. Yet at one time to me this chip had purpose.
Like reading an old flash drive from a box of them you have.
At one time this was important, having a look is not a crime.

Automatically accusing everyone of code theft needs to end.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: GAL JED files are generally not generated from a schematic, but from a set of logic equations. There are two programs I know of that can 'decompile' JED files back into equations:\-

1. JED2EQN, included in National Semiconductor's [OPALjr](https://vetusware.com/manufacturer/National%20Semiconductor/?author=6024) PAL/GAL programming suite, which runs in DOS.
2. [GALer](http://aminet.net/package/driver/other/GALer21), a GAL programmer for [Amiga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amiga) computers. If you don't have an Amiga you can [emulate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_(emulator)) it on a PC or Mac. Alternatively you could compile the necessary source code (which is written in C) for your preferred platform.

Once you have the equations, converting them to a schematic diagram is relatively easy.

33.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A developer has an old GAL 16V8 JED file from a project created 30 years ago and wants to understand its logic. What is the most appropriate approach to decode this JED file into a more readable format?

A) Use a modern schematic capture tool to directly import the JED file and generate a gate-level schematic
B) Manually reverse-engineer the JEDEC file by hand-drawing logic maps
C) Utilize a JED decompiler like JED2EQN or GALer to convert the JED file back into logic equations
D) Contact the original chip manufacturer to request proprietary decoding software

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most appropriate approach is to use a JED decompiler like JED2EQN (part of National Semiconductor's OPALjr suite) or GALer to convert the JED file back into logic equations. This method allows for easier interpretation of the GAL's functionality without manual reverse-engineering. Option A is incorrect because most modern schematic tools don't directly import JED files. Option B, while possible, is time-consuming and error-prone. Option D is impractical, as manufacturers typically don't provide such services for old products.

\#\#\# User: When a square wave is applied to a transmission line which is not terminated with its characteristic impedance, reflection and ringing occur. 

I don't understand how sinusoidal ringing occurs when I apply a square wave.

I really don't understand the mechanism of reflection in case of square wave. 

When a square wave is applied, is the square wave reflected or are its harmonics reflected?

If harmonics are reflected, why?

Edit: The present answer and comments clarifies regarding the above questions. I mainly wanted to know the case why ringing is observed in the open circuit termination at both ends. What is the mechanism behind it? 

Please consider answering the questions in edit.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: We'll start with what a square wave is.

A [square wave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_wave#Fourier_analysis) is a bunch of sine waves added together. You have a primary, and a bunch of harmonics added to it. The harmonics are in a particular phase relationship to the primary. The sum of all the waves is a square wave. If you leave any of the sine waves out (or change their phase,) then the sum looks less like an ideal sine wave.

This image from the Wikipedia page illustrates it clearly:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/sdaUx.gif)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/sdaUx.gif)

Now, on to the reflections.

If your transmission line were terminated in a perfect resistor that doesn't match the line impedance (and there were no effects from capacitance or inductance) then the reflection would be a nice, sharp copy of your original square wave.

In any real circuit, you will have capacitances and inductances to deal with.

The inductance, capacitance, and resistance of your transmission line will interact with the inductance, capacitance, and resistance of the termination. The result is an impedance that varies with frequency.

A square wave is a collection of sine waves of different frequencies, so different parts of it are more or less strongly reflected. Some frequencies will be slightly delayed, and some won't.

The result is often that some part is reflected as a somewhat proper looking square wave while other parts are reflected differently enough that you can see the sine wave itself.

When neither end is properly terminated, then each sine in the square wave is reflected depending where exactly it "hits the end." 

Say you have a transmission line 1 meter long, and a wave one meter long. In this case, there will be no reflection \- the wave fits exactly in the transmission line.

Now keep the 1 meter transmission line, but change to a wave that is 67 centimeters long. The wave doesn't fit exactly in the transmission line anymore. Part of it will be reflected.

Put the one meter wave and the 67 centimeter wave into the same transmission line at the same time, and you will only see reflections from the 67 centimeter wave.

Now consider your square wave (made of waves of different lengths.) Some parts will reflect more strongly than other parts. If most of the sine waves reflect together, then you might get something that looks like a square wave. You might also get a situation where only a few (or one) frequency reflects strongly \- in which case you get something that looks like a sine wave as a reflection. That's ringing.

34.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A square wave signal is applied to a transmission line with mismatched impedance at both ends. Which of the following best describes the resulting reflections and ringing phenomenon?

A) Only the fundamental frequency of the square wave is reflected, resulting in a pure sine wave ringing.

B) The entire square wave is reflected intact, maintaining its original shape without any distortion.

C) Different frequency components of the square wave are reflected differently based on the transmission line characteristics, potentially resulting in a combination of square-like reflections and sinusoidal ringing.

D) Only the highest frequency harmonics are reflected, causing high-frequency oscillations without any resemblance to the original square wave.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because a square wave is composed of multiple sine wave components (fundamental and harmonics). In a mismatched transmission line, these different frequency components interact differently with the line's impedance characteristics. Some frequencies may be reflected more strongly or with different phase shifts than others. This can result in a complex reflection pattern where parts of the signal may maintain a square-like appearance while others exhibit sinusoidal ringing. The overall reflection and ringing are a result of how these various frequency components are reflected and combine at the terminations. This explanation aligns with the complex behavior described in the original text, accounting for the interaction between the square wave's composition and the transmission line's frequency-dependent impedance characteristics.

\#\#\# User: How can I count the number of integer solutions, $\\mu(n)$, of $x^2\+y^2 \< n$, and then hopefully look at behavior as $n \\to \+\\infty$?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The behaviour as $n\\to\\infty$ is simpler than counting exactly in the finite case:
You count exactly the integer points in a circle of radius $\\sqrt n$. Since the circle is not too "chaotic", the number of points is essentially the area of the circle: $\\mu(n)\\sim \\pi n$.

39.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Consider the function μ(n) that counts the number of integer solutions to x^2 + y^2 < n. As n approaches infinity, which of the following best describes the asymptotic behavior of μ(n)?

A) μ(n) ~ n log(n)
B) μ(n) ~ πn
C) μ(n) ~ n^(3/2)
D) μ(n) ~ 2πn

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B: μ(n) ~ πn. 

This asymptotic behavior can be understood as follows:

1. The inequality x^2 + y^2 < n describes a circle with radius √n in the xy-plane.
2. μ(n) counts the number of integer points inside this circle.
3. As n becomes very large, the number of integer points closely approximates the area of the circle.
4. The area of a circle with radius r is πr^2.
5. In this case, r = √n, so the area is π(√n)^2 = πn.

Therefore, as n approaches infinity, the number of integer solutions μ(n) is asymptotically equivalent to πn.

Option A is incorrect because n log(n) grows faster than πn.
Option C is incorrect because n^(3/2) grows much faster than πn.
Option D is incorrect because 2πn is off by a factor of 2.

This question tests understanding of asymptotic behavior, geometric interpretation of inequalities, and the relationship between discrete point counting and continuous area calculations.

If you scroll down in the 'Algorithms' section on the linked webpage, you can see these two equations the translational and rotational equations given as follows.

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/y2dDh.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/y2dDh.png)

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/cI6mM.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/cI6mM.png)

In the translational equation, I see the term $V\_{re}$. I understand that is the velocity of mass flow relative to body. But in the rotational equation, I don't see a similar corresponding term such as the 'relative angular velocity $\\omega\_{re}$'. I thought the mass flow has it own angular velocity and angular momentum when it is added or ejected from the body. Why does the rotational equation not include the relative angular velocity of the mass flow?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Two spherical objects A and B are at rest in empty space and are charged in such a way that the net force between them (gravitational and electromagnetic) is exactly zero.

Dale's answer seems to suggest that this isn't possible in general relativity because gravity isn't a force, but I think that's wrong, or at least misleading.

If the cosmological constant is zero, there's [a family of exact solutions to GR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudhansu_Datta_Majumdar#Majumdar%E2%80%94Papapetrou_solution) describing black holes at relative rest with their charges and masses proportional such that there is no net relative force between them. There's no reason (I think) that you couldn't replace the black holes with lumps of ordinary matter.

If the cosmological constant is positive, then in addition to the usual attractive force, there is an effective repulsive force proportional to $r$ (not $1/r^2$). It should be possible in principle to counter this by decreasing the charge on the bodies, though not realistically in practice since it would be an unstable equilibrium. I'll assume for the rest of this answer that it is possible.

> After a certain period of time, the space between the two objects is measured to have expanded.

No, it won't expand. This is the key misunderstanding. We constructed this system to be static, and static it is. The distance between the objects will not change over time.

The only reason the universe is expanding is that (for unknown reasons, possibly related to inflation) it was expanding in the past, and it wasn't dense enough for gravity to stop and reverse the outward inertia. In recent times, the repulsive force due to the cosmological constant has become large enough to be important, but we countered that too in this system. There's nothing else that would make the distance between the objects increase. The universe doesn't *want* to expand. There is no physical process that enforces the expansion by inserting space between objects. I wrote [another answer](/a/601323) about this.

The information provided states that it is possible to construct a static system where two charged objects remain at rest relative to each other, even in the context of general relativity. The key point is that such a system, once set up, would remain static - the distance between the objects would not change over time. The expansion of the universe does not inherently cause objects to move apart if other forces are keeping them in place. Options A and D are incorrect because they suggest movement that wouldn't occur in this carefully balanced system. Option B is incorrect because, while gravity is treated differently in general relativity, the scenario described is still possible with the right conditions.

\#\#\# User: I would like to know how to make a sentence with 'determine'.

for example, I want to determine a recommendation blog by selecting a blog which has a high quality score from among a plurality of blogs.

So, should I say 'determine a blog which has a high score as a recommendation blog'? 
or should I say 'determine(decide) a blog which has a high score to be a recommendation blog.?

I mean, it's like setting something as A. but I don't know if it's the right way to say 'determining/deciding something as" or 'to be'.

Thanks in advance 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Judging by definition \#2 when [Googling](https://www.google.com/search?client=safari&rls=en&q=determine&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8), *determine* implies an exact thing, like an answer to something. Perhaps like the answer to: "which blog will I recommend?"  

Therefore, I don't believe either of your suggestions are exactly correct, although I believe your intent would probably be understood. 

One does not typically *determine* **a** blog.  

One might determine **that** a particular blog is useful / fun / interesting / of value.  

Or you could determine **the** blog that you will recommend, but **a** blog is usually not just *determined.* 

Also, I've never heard the term *recommendation blog* used quite like that, unless you mean that it is a blog featuring recommendations.  

I think you would prefer to say you'd like to: 

> determine **the** blog you will recommend, based on it's high score.

or 

> determine **the** blog with the highest score, which I will use as my recommend**ed** blog.

\#\#\# User: I was walking with a friend and we saw a sign that said

> Do not park here your motorbike. Thank you.

To me, it looks incorrect, and I think the correct sentence should be

> Do not park your motorbike here. Thank you.

My friend insisted that the order of the words could be changed, though, and that the first sentence is correct.

Are both sentences correct?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In this sentence, [here](http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/here) is an **adverb of place** that applies to the verb **park**. 

According to [this guide](http://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/adverbs-and-adverb-phrases-position), it is normal to put adverbs of place at the end of a clause. They sometimes go at the start of the clause.

> Do not park your motorbike here. Thank you. *\- this follows the guide*
> 
> 
> Do not park here your motorbike. Thank you. *\- this does not*

As per the [pirates code](http://piratesonline.wikia.com/wiki/Pirate's_Code), it's more a guideline than a rule.

For example, it is possible to put information [other than the direct object](https://www.grammarly.com/handbook/grammar/adjectives-and-adverbs/28/an-adverb-between-a-verb-and-its-direct-object/) after the adverb:

> We will be there at that table *\- this is OK*
> 
> 
> Do not park here your motorbike *\- this is not OK*

The correct answer acknowledges the flexibility in adverb placement while recognizing that there are typical patterns that are generally followed.

\#\#\# User: I've a scanned PDF and i can't seem to highlight the text of course using the preview on my OS X, is there a software that do that like in windows?

Thanks

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Highlighting text in a PDF assumes that there is text in the PDF to begin with.

When you scan a document to PDF, it is simply an image. You should still be able to use the annotation tools available in preview to draw on it and add notes, but you will not be able to highlight or copy text from it because there literally is no text in the document.

There is, however, a type of software called OCR, for Optical Character Recognition, that can be used to programmatically "read" the letters in the image of your document and write out accurate text to the PDF. Some of this software is pretty good, but it is rarely free. Some scanners come with OCR software, and the you may be able to find some software [online](http://finereader.abbyy.com) that will let you try it out for free.

**Running an image PDF through OCR software will provide it with text data that you can then highlight using the annotation tools in preview.**

B) The scanned PDF contains only image data without underlying text, requiring OCR software to add selectable text.
C) The PDF file is corrupted and needs to be rescanned with different scanner settings.
D) The highlighting feature is disabled in the PDF security settings and needs to be unlocked.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: When a document is scanned into a PDF, it creates an image of the page rather than readable text. This means there is no actual text data for the PDF reader to interact with for highlighting or copying. The solution is to use Optical Character Recognition (OCR) software, which can analyze the image and add a layer of selectable text to the PDF. Once this is done, the student would be able to highlight and copy text as needed. Options A, C, and D are incorrect as they do not address the fundamental issue of the lack of text data in a scanned PDF.

Question: A developer is implementing logging in a PHP application using Monolog. They want to capture the filename, method name, and line number where each log entry is created. Which of the following approaches would best achieve this goal?

Option A is incorrect because creating a new Logger instance for each log entry is inefficient and wouldn't solve the problem of capturing the correct filename and method name.

Option B, while a possible workaround, is not the best practice as it relies on global state and doesn't follow object-oriented principles.

Option C is the correct answer. Implementing dependency injection allows for a single, properly configured Logger instance to be used throughout the application. By injecting the Logger into the classes that need it, you ensure that the correct context (filename, method name, line number) is captured when logging.

Option D is incorrect because modifying the LineFormatter alone wouldn't provide the necessary information about where the log entry was created. The issue is more about how and where the Logger is instantiated and used, rather than its output format.

The correct approach (C) also allows for the use of the IntrospectionProcessor, which can automatically capture the filename, method name, and line number where each log entry is created.

2. It sets the text color to gray directly in the node options.
3. It uses 'font=\tiny' to reduce the font size.
4. Most importantly, it includes '\linespread{0.8}\selectfont', which reduces the line spacing between the lines of text.
5. The '\selectfont' command is crucial as it activates the new line spacing.

Option A uses the older 'text width=0' approach and doesn't address the line spacing issue.
Option B correctly uses 'align=left' and sets the color and font size, but doesn't adjust the line spacing.
Option D incorrectly combines 'text width=0' with 'line spacing=0.8', which is not a valid TikZ option for adjusting line spacing.

\#\#\# User: The word or concept I'm after is the system where a user of a service can transfer real money to their account (top\-up), receive "credits", use those credits somehow inside the system, and then exchange the credits back to real currency (check\-out). These "credits" wouldn't officially be recognized as a currency.

The concepts that I think are closest to what I'm looking for are *[complementary currency](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complementary_currency)* and *[scrip](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrip)*, but neither seems to be correct in my opinion.

**Update:**

No matter how I try to read *credit*'s wiki definition, the *'provides resources to another party and arranges to repay those resources at a later date'* doesn't seem to fit. As told, the purpose of these "credits" for which I try to find a better word for are, to be used as a form of currency inside the service.

This made me think of casino chips, which led me to another interesting contender: exonumia, which unfortunately appears to only be used in the context of physical items.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: * *credit* 

> “ *The trust which allows one party to provide resources to another party where that second party does not reimburse the first party immediately (thereby generating a debt), but instead arranges either to repay or return those resources (or other materials of equal value) at a later date.*  
> 
>  \- Wikipedia, *Credit* (as of June 26, 2014 09:30, UTC)

While the word doesn't appear to be correct by definition, it apparently is understood by many so as to justify it's usage when referring to virtual currency in a service.
* *virtual currency* 

> “ *A type of unregulated, digital money, which is issued and usually controlled by its developers, and used and accepted among the members of a specific virtual community.*  
> 
>  \- Wikipedia, *Credit* (as of June 26, 2014 09:30, UTC)

Most unambiguous, but may be hard to use in writing due to not being succinct.

Question: A popular online gaming platform allows users to purchase in-game "coins" with real money. These coins can be used to buy virtual items within games, and any unused coins can be converted back to real currency. Which of the following terms best describes this system of digital value exchange?

A) Complementary currency
B) Scrip
C) Virtual currency
D) Exonumia

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) Complementary currency is incorrect. While it refers to a currency that can be used alongside standard national currencies, it typically operates within a specific community or region and is not exclusively digital.

B) Scrip is incorrect. Although scrip can refer to a substitute for legal tender, it is often associated with physical tokens or vouchers rather than digital systems.

C) Virtual currency is the correct answer. It accurately describes the digital nature of the "coins" used within the gaming platform, which are unregulated, controlled by the developers, and accepted within the specific virtual community of the gaming platform.

D) Exonumia is incorrect. This term refers to numismatic items other than coins and paper money, typically physical items like tokens or medals, and does not apply to digital currency systems.

Virtual currency best captures the essence of the described system, where users can purchase, use, and exchange digital "coins" within a specific online platform.

\#\#\# User: I have a regular time series of accumulated values of a variable (usage) with some missing (sometimes consecutive) intervals.

Is there an imputation method that methodologically considers this additional information and requirement that the values must add up when it returns the imputed values?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Ok you have a time series like this:

spend budget:
0, 30, 90, 110, NA, 210, NA, NA, 333,400, NA, 410

So what you probably want to be considered is that:

1. The NA replacement is bigger than the value before the NA
2. The NA replacement is smaller than the value after the NA
3. This still applies for for consecutive missing values

Well, the solution is easy.
Linear Interpolation will fulfill this rules all the time.
(and actually also gives decent results)

But also all other (advanced) time series methods will recognize the clear trend in the data and make use of this. 
To get a feeling, what are common time series imputation methods, you could have a look at the manual of my time series imputation R package ([imputeTS manual](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/imputeTS/imputeTS.pdf)).

B) Linear interpolation will always fulfill the requirement that imputed values are larger than the previous known value and smaller than the next known value, even for consecutive missing values.

C) Advanced time series methods cannot recognize the trend in this data due to the presence of missing values.

D) The accumulated nature of the data means that no imputation method can provide reliable estimates for the missing values.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Linear interpolation is specifically mentioned in the documentation as a method that will always fulfill the rules of the imputed value being larger than the previous known value and smaller than the next known value, even for consecutive missing values. This makes B the correct answer. 

Option A is incorrect because while polynomial interpolation can be used, it's not the only method that ensures this condition, and linear interpolation is explicitly mentioned as fulfilling this requirement. 

Option C is incorrect because the documentation states that advanced time series methods will recognize the clear trend in the data and make use of it. 

Option D is incorrect because the documentation suggests that imputation methods can be applied effectively to this type of data, and does not indicate that the accumulated nature prevents reliable estimation.

\#\#\# User: I'm currently in the processes of remodeling a home built in 1900 or even earlier. It has balloon framing and true dimensional lumber. I removed the lath and plaster on the walls and behind some of the exterior walls I found large wood planks that run horizontally.

It's not shiplap because there is no tongue and groove, I can see between the cracks and see old insulation.

My intuition tells me they are structural, and are being used as sheathing. However, the exterior of the wall has some wood siding that is about 1/8 to 1/4 inch thick. So I'm not sure if these wood planks are necessary. Is this something that was commonly done at the time to hold in insulation? Or a trick to make it easier to install the lath and plaster?

Can I remove these planks? I would like to put in new wiring and insulation.

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/KhuwV.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/KhuwV.jpg)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It is possible that those planks were purposely added for sheer strength. If you live in a location with high winds and storms then those planks provide lateral resistance against those forces. If your sill or sole plate is anchored to the foundation then additionally you have earthquake resistance. Your house won't readily topple if you remove them but you'll be sorry after a single bad storm.

I would remove them only with the intention of putting them back after routing utilities and adding proper insulation.

It does concern me that there is no sheathing on the outside of your home, only siding. It means that water will have a much easier time infiltrating your wall cavities and will ruin your insulation efforts unless you go with rockwool.

52.answer:

Question: In a home built around 1900 with balloon framing, large horizontal wood planks were found behind the exterior walls after removing lath and plaster. What is the most likely purpose of these planks, and what should be done with them during renovation?

A) They are decorative and can be safely removed without replacement.
B) They are for insulation only and can be replaced with modern materials.
C) They provide structural support and should be removed then reinstalled after adding utilities and insulation.
D) They are a moisture barrier and should be replaced with modern vapor barriers.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The planks likely serve a structural purpose, providing shear strength against lateral forces like high winds and storms. They also offer some earthquake resistance if the sill plate is anchored to the foundation. Removing them permanently could compromise the home's structural integrity. The best approach is to carefully remove them to add utilities and proper insulation, then reinstall them to maintain the home's structural strength. This method preserves the original design while allowing for modern improvements.

\#\#\# User: I want to start Cygwin and it should instantly connect to some server:

```
$ ssh user@1.1.1.1

```

for example, how I can achieve this?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You could create a Windows shortcut with the target set like so (and an icon of your choice):

```
C:\cygwin\bin\ssh.exe user@1.1.1.1

```

Or, for better terminal emulation than in the default console window, run it in [mintty](http://mintty.googlecode.com), setting the shortcut target like this:

```
C:\cygwin\bin\mintty.exe /bin/ssh user@1.1.1.1

```

   C:\cygwin\bin\ssh.exe user@1.1.1.1

D) Create a shortcut with the target:
   C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c ssh user@1.1.1.1

This setup will launch Cygwin's mintty terminal and immediately execute the SSH command to connect to the specified server.

Option A is partially correct as it would work, but it doesn't use mintty for improved terminal emulation. Option C incorrectly uses bash.exe instead of directly calling ssh. Option D incorrectly uses the Windows command prompt instead of Cygwin's environment.

\#\#\# User: I am trying to convert Maxwell's equations from the well known differential form (found on Wikipedia [Maxwell's equations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell%27s_equations)) into scalar equations involving partial derivatives (more than four equations). The problem I'm having is finding the definitions of physical quantities. I'm not sure how charge density and current density are expressed in euclidean space. How are these expressed? What are Maxwell's Equations expressed in this way?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> I'm not sure how charge density and current density are expressed in euclidean space.

Charge density $\\rho$ is just a scalar density (measured in Coulomb/m$^3$).  

And current density $\\vec{J}$ is a vector density (with cartesian components
$J\_x, J\_y, J\_z$, measured in Ampere/m$^2$).

> What are Maxwell's Equations expressed in this way?

[Maxwell's equations (written with vector\-calculus)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell%27s_equations#Alternative_formulations) are given by
$$
\\begin{align}
\\vec{\\nabla}\\cdot\\vec{B} \&\= 0 \\tag{1a} \\\\
\\vec{\\nabla}\\cdot\\vec{E} \&\= \\frac{\\rho}{\\epsilon\_0} \\tag{1b} \\\\
\\vec{\\nabla}\\times\\vec{E} \+ \\frac{\\partial\\vec{B}}{\\partial t} \&\= \\vec{0} \\tag{1c} \\\\
\\vec{\\nabla}\\times\\vec{B} \- \\frac{1}{c^2} \\frac{\\partial\\vec{E}}{\\partial t} \&\= \\mu\_0\\vec{J} \\tag{1d} \\\\
\\end{align}
$$

Using the definitions of [divergence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divergence#Cartesian_coordinates) ($\\vec{\\nabla}\\cdot$)
and [curl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curl_(mathematics)#Usage) ($\\vec{\\nabla}\\times$) it is straight\-forward
to write the above equations with the cartesian field components
($E\_x,E\_y,E\_z,B\_x,B\_y,B\_z$) in [cartesian coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian_coordinate_system) ($x,y,z$).

The scalar equations (1a) and (1b) each remain one equation.  

The vector equations (1c) and (1d) each expand to three equations (for $x, y, z$ components).
$$
\\begin{align}
\\frac{\\partial B\_x}{\\partial x} \+ \\frac{\\partial B\_y}{\\partial y} \+ \\frac{\\partial B\_z}{\\partial z} \&\= 0 \\\\
\& \\\\
\\frac{\\partial E\_x}{\\partial x} \+ \\frac{\\partial E\_y}{\\partial y} \+ \\frac{\\partial E\_z}{\\partial z} \&\= \\frac{\\rho}{\\epsilon\_0} \\\\
\& \\\\
\\frac{\\partial E\_z}{\\partial y} \- \\frac{\\partial E\_y}{\\partial z} \+ \\frac{\\partial B\_x}{\\partial t} \&\= 0 \\\\
\\frac{\\partial E\_x}{\\partial z} \- \\frac{\\partial E\_z}{\\partial x} \+ \\frac{\\partial B\_y}{\\partial t} \&\= 0 \\\\
\\frac{\\partial E\_y}{\\partial x} \- \\frac{\\partial E\_x}{\\partial y} \+ \\frac{\\partial B\_z}{\\partial t} \&\= 0 \\\\
\& \\\\
\\frac{\\partial B\_z}{\\partial y} \- \\frac{\\partial B\_y}{\\partial z} \- \\frac{1}{c^2}\\frac{\\partial E\_x}{\\partial t} \&\= \\mu\_0 J\_x \\\\
\\frac{\\partial B\_x}{\\partial z} \- \\frac{\\partial B\_z}{\\partial x} \- \\frac{1}{c^2}\\frac{\\partial E\_y}{\\partial t} \&\= \\mu\_0 J\_y \\\\
\\frac{\\partial B\_y}{\\partial x} \- \\frac{\\partial B\_x}{\\partial y} \- \\frac{1}{c^2}\\frac{\\partial E\_z}{\\partial t} \&\= \\mu\_0 J\_z
\\end{align}
$$

54.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given Maxwell's equations documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements about Maxwell's equations in scalar form is correct?

A) The divergence of the magnetic field (∇·B) always results in three separate scalar equations.

B) The curl of the electric field (∇×E) produces two scalar equations, one for each spatial dimension.

C) The equation ∂Bx/∂x + ∂By/∂y + ∂Bz/∂z = 0 represents the divergence of the magnetic field in scalar form.

D) The scalar form of Maxwell's equations always results in exactly 6 separate equations.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because the divergence of the magnetic field (∇·B) results in a single scalar equation, not three.

B is incorrect because the curl of the electric field (∇×E) produces three scalar equations, one for each spatial dimension (x, y, z), not two.

C is correct. The equation ∂Bx/∂x + ∂By/∂y + ∂Bz/∂z = 0 is indeed the scalar form of the divergence of the magnetic field (∇·B = 0).

D is incorrect because the scalar form of Maxwell's equations results in 8 separate equations: 1 from ∇·B, 1 from ∇·E, 3 from ∇×E, and 3 from ∇×B.

\#\#\# User: If my iPhone 4 dies, will it turn back on automatically after I put it on charge?

The reason I ask this is my lock button is broken and I'm afraid to let my phone die. What should I do?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes, it will turn on once it reaches the minimum charge needed to start the phone.

When the battery is completely drained, you would just see a depleted battery icon (with a connect to charger prompt) for a few seconds if you press the Sleep/Wake button or the Home button. Once you connect it to the charger, it will charge for a few minutes and automatically start up, taking you to the lock screen.

At any time, you can wake your phone by pressing either the Sleep/Wake button (on top) or the Home button (below the touchscreen).

A) The phone will remain off until the user presses the Home button, regardless of the charge level.
B) The phone will turn on immediately upon connecting to the charger, even if the battery is still at 0%.
C) The phone will automatically turn on once it reaches a minimum charge threshold, without user intervention.
D) The phone will display a depleted battery icon indefinitely until the user manually restarts it using a combination of button presses.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the documentation, when an iPhone's battery is completely drained and then connected to a charger, it will charge for a few minutes until it reaches the minimum charge needed to start the phone. At this point, it will automatically turn on and take the user to the lock screen, without requiring any manual intervention. 

Option A is incorrect because the phone will turn on automatically, not requiring the user to press the Home button. 
Option B is false because the phone needs to reach a minimum charge before it can turn on; it doesn't happen immediately upon connection. 
Option D is incorrect as the depleted battery icon is only shown briefly if buttons are pressed while the battery is dead, and the phone will start automatically once sufficiently charged.

This question tests the candidate's understanding of device behavior in low-battery situations and the automatic recovery process when charging begins.

\#\#\# User: I believe the interpretation of the p\-value is that it is the probability of seeing your sample's test statistic under the null hypothesis.

But what happens if you perform the same exact test multiple times and get multiple p\-values? Could you use the multiplication rule from probability to multiply the first p\-value by the second, thus getting a new overall probability of seeing your test statistic?

e.g. you do a t\-test and get a p\-value of 0\.05, and then you perform the same test with a completely different sample and get a p\-value of 0\.10\. In this case, the probability of seeing those two test statistics under the null hypothesis would be $0\.05 \\times 0\.1 \= 0\.005$, which is a less likely and thus more significant value?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: "I believe the interpretation of the p\-value is that it is the probability of seeing your sample's test statistic under the null hypothesis."

No. It is the probability to see your sample's test statistic *or something that is even less in line with the null hypothesis* ($H\_0$) under the $H\_0$, which I write as $P\_0\\{T\\ge t\\}$, where $T$ is the test statistic and $t$ is its observed value, assuming here that a large value of $T$ provides evidence against $H\_0$ (the argument can as well be made for the $\\{T\\le t\\}$ or the two\-sided case).

If you have, say, $p\=0\.06$ in one test $T\_1$ with result $t\_1$ and $p\=0\.6$ in the next ($T\_2, t\_2$; let's assume they were done on independent observations), if you multiply these two, what you get is the probability of $\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\} \\cap \\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\}$, i.e., the probability that $T\_1$ *and* $T\_2$ are large under the $H\_0$. This is of course less likely than having at least one of them large. But there are cases with at least one of them large that count at least as strongly against the $H\_0$, such as having $T\_1$ extremely large even if $T\_2$ doesn't indicate problems with the $H\_0$, so the event $\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\} \\cap \\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\}$, of which you get the probability by multiplying the p\-values, does not cover all possibilities to observe *something that is even less in line with the $H\_0$* than what you observed, and is therefore smaller than a valid "combined" p\-value would need to be.

In my example above, surely after having observed $t\_1$ with $P\_0\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\}\=0\.06$, observing $t\_2$ with $P\_0\\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\}\=0\.6$ doesn't make the overall result indicate any stronger against the $H\_0$ (as multiplying the p\-values would suggest), because observing something with $P\_0\\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\}\=0\.6$ is perfectly reasonable under $H\_0$; however observing $T\_1$ even larger than $t\_1$ would arguably count stronger against $H\_0$ even with observing a smaller $T\_2$.

The problem with combining p\-values from more than one test is that if you only have a one\-dimensional test statistic, as long as this statistic is suitably defined, it is clear how you can find all possible outcomes that are less in line with $H\_0$ than your observation (depending on the test statistic either by looking at all larger, or all smaller values, or combining the two sides). However, with two or more values of the test statistic, in the higher dimensional space of possible outcomes it is much more difficult to define what "less in line with $H\_0$" actually means. One possibility to play it safe is to look at $P\_0(\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\}\\cup\\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\})$, the probability that at least one of $T\_1$ and $T\_2$ is too large. This for sure covers all possibilities that the pair $(T\_1,T\_2\)$ is less in line with $H\_0$ than the observations $(t\_1,t\_2\)$. It actually covers far too much and is therefore very conservative. It may in fact be seen as useless, because its probability will always be bigger than $P\_0\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\}$, so this won't allow you to find a significance based on $(T\_1,T\_2\)$ if you don't find one based on $T\_1$ alone. If the two tests are independent, as apparently assumed here, $P\_0(\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\}\\cup\\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\})\=1\-(1\-P\_0\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\})(1\-P\_0\\{T\_2\\ge t\_1\\})\=0\.624$ in the example, so there you have your multiplication.

Note that $2\\min(P\_0\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\},P\_0\\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\})\=0\.12$ in the example is the so\-called Bonferroni\-corrected p\-value, which gives an upper bound on the probability that any of the two indicates at least as much against $H\_0$ than the one that has the stronger indication, which is somewhat better than $P\_0(\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\}\\cup\\{T\_2\\ge t\_2\\})$, but still will not allow you to have an overall combined p\-value that is smaller than all those you observe for the isolated tests. Under independence this can be improved to $1\-(1\-\\min (P\_0\\{T\_1\\ge t\_1\\},P\_0\\{T\_2\\ge t\_1\\}))^2\=0\.116$, not much change here. (Edit: Fisher's method as linked in the answer of gunes will normally be better than this in the independence case.)

56.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A researcher conducts two independent t-tests on different samples and obtains p-values of 0.06 and 0.6 respectively. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the combination of these p-values?

A) Multiplying the p-values (0.06 × 0.6 = 0.036) gives a valid combined p-value that is more significant than either individual test.

B) The combined p-value should be calculated as 1-(1-0.06)(1-0.6) = 0.624, which represents the probability of at least one test being significant.

C) The Bonferroni-corrected p-value of 2 × min(0.06, 0.6) = 0.12 is the most appropriate method for combining these p-values.

D) No valid conclusion can be drawn about the overall significance by combining these two p-values, as the second test (p = 0.6) does not provide evidence against the null hypothesis.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option D is correct because the second test with p = 0.6 does not provide evidence against the null hypothesis, and combining it with the first test does not strengthen the overall evidence. Option A is incorrect because simply multiplying p-values doesn't account for all possibilities less in line with the null hypothesis. Option B, while mathematically correct for the probability of at least one significant result, is too conservative and doesn't provide a useful combined p-value. Option C, the Bonferroni correction, is overly conservative and not the most appropriate in this case. The key insight is that combining p-values from multiple tests is complex and can be misleading, especially when one test shows no evidence against the null hypothesis.

\#\#\# User: I'm exploring methods of tracking the changes that happen to the kernel defconfig for a particular board. The changes I'm referring to are either selecting a new option through the menuconfig and persisting that, or moving to a new kernel that introduces new options.

My idea is to remove comments and sort the defconfig before committing the changes:

```
make ARCH=arm board_defconfig
make ARCH=arm menuconfig       # Changes introduced here and saved to .config
make ARCH=arm savedefconfig    # This creates the defconfig file
grep -v '^#' defconfig > tmp
sort tmp > tmp_sorted
uniq tmp_sorted > defconfig
cp savedefconfig arch/arm/configs/board_defconfig

```

`menuconfig` however has a very consistent habit of adding comment line. For example:

```
# CONFIG_IOMMU_SUPPORT is not set
# CONFIG_RTC_INTF_PROC is not set
# CONFIG_IOMMU_SUPPORT is not set

```

which makes me have second thoughts if I'm actually allowed to remove them.

Is there a purpose to these comment lines making them unsafe to remove?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The objective answer is:

The comment lines can safely be removed. Here is a [reference](http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/SCSI-2.4-HOWTO/kconfig.html) for that claim.

You can double check the configuration using menuconfig (or nconfig in more recent kernels) to validate whether the commented sections in fact hold the default values as per your preference.

B) Removing comment lines is safe, but it's recommended to keep them for better readability and future reference.
C) Comment lines can be safely removed without affecting the kernel's configuration, and their removal can be validated using menuconfig or nconfig.
D) Only comment lines referring to disabled configurations (e.g., "# CONFIG_IOMMU_SUPPORT is not set") can be safely removed.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the reference provided in the top answer, comment lines in the kernel defconfig file can be safely removed without affecting the kernel's configuration. The answer also suggests that after removing these lines, you can use menuconfig (or nconfig in more recent kernel versions) to validate that the configuration still holds the desired values. This approach allows for a cleaner, more compact defconfig file while ensuring that the actual kernel configuration remains intact. Options A and D are incorrect because they overstate the importance of the comment lines. Option B, while not entirely wrong about readability, is not the most accurate answer given the context of the question and the provided information.

\#\#\# User: I am looking for a word or a short phrase for people who frequently hypothesize and contemplate. Please help me out. I need use this word to give a title to an article that deals with such people as I've described. These are just general people, who happen to dream and ponder a lot over hypothetical possibilities.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The difference between "in", "by", and "with" in this context actually depends on the nature or type of disappointment you feel:

"Disappointed with" implies that the cause of the disappointment was something basic about the nature or attributes of the thing:

> I was disappointed with my new toaster. It really didn't toast the bread as well as I hoped.

The "with" form is usually used with inanimate objects (like toasters), though can sometimes be used for people if you're expressing a general disappointment about their qualifications/abilities/etc, rather than being disappointed by any specific thing that they've done:

> I was disappointed with the second candidate. He didn't really have the skills we need for the job.

On the other hand, "disappointed by" usually indicates that somebody has done something specific to cause you to be disappointed:

> I was disappointed by Fred. He said he'd give me a ride, but he never showed up!

(The "by" form is occasionally used with objects, but most of the time only makes sense for people.)

"Disappointed in" usually indicates a deeper level of disappointment with the nature of somebody or something, or repeated problems with them, and often indicates that the speaker has lost faith in someone's ability to do what's expected of them:

> I'm very disappointed in Bill. I thought he had experience with this job, but every time he does it he does something wrong.

or

> I'm disappointed in the government. They just can't seem to get anything done!

Question: Sarah has been having issues with her new smartphone. It frequently crashes, the battery life is poor, and the camera quality is subpar compared to what was advertised. Which of the following statements best expresses Sarah's likely sentiment?

A) Sarah is disappointed by her new smartphone.
B) Sarah is disappointed in her new smartphone.
C) Sarah is disappointed with her new smartphone.
D) Sarah is disappointed for her new smartphone.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
C is the correct answer because "disappointed with" is typically used when expressing disappointment about the basic nature or attributes of an object. In this case, Sarah is disappointed with various features and performance aspects of her smartphone.

A is incorrect because "disappointed by" is usually used when someone has done something specific to cause disappointment, and is more commonly used with people rather than objects.

B is incorrect because "disappointed in" typically indicates a deeper level of disappointment, often involving repeated problems or loss of faith in someone's abilities. While this could potentially apply here, it's more commonly used for people or institutions rather than objects.

D is incorrect because "disappointed for" is not a standard construction in this context. It might be used to express sympathy for someone else's disappointment, but not to describe one's own disappointment with an object.

documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have open source C\# .NET project at GitHub with Appveyor CI \+ code coverage. 

There are configurations like **Release** and **Debug**. There's also platforms like **x86**, **x64** and **Any CPU**.

This results to following:

```
Configuration | Platform | Tests
--------------+----------+--------
Release       | x86      | 100/100
Release       | x64      | 100/100
Release       | Any CPU  | 100/100
Debug         | x86      | 100/100
Debug         | x64      | 100/100
Debug         | Any CPU  | 100/100

```

Should unit tests run always on all of the combinations (six) of these two dimensions when application is in development stage? ie. mainly only developers are in the process and lots of changes are taking place. 

My intuition says that only **Debug** configuration and one platform should be tested.

My view is that **Debug** configuration gives more information and as C\# being quite high level language and running in VM (CLR) there's no need to test **x64** and **x86** separately.

There's also third dimension with .NET framework version. And fourth with OS.

Is there best practises view in the field of what is or isn't necessary when application is being developed?

When shipping all tests are of course ran. Same with possible nightly/weekly/etc builds.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This has nothing to do with "a common view in the field" \- this is all about what makes sense most.

Running unit tests (or any kind of automated tests) using only one configuration and only one platform is fine as long as the code under test as well as the test itself don't show any indications for behaving differently under different configurations and platforms (except for performance, of course).

In a ideal world, there is only one configuration required for running the tests. However, certain kind of code constructs or statements are more prone to behave differently in "Debug" and "Release", or differently in "x86" or "x64". There are obvious things

* like explicit tests `#if DEBUG`, and not so obvious things like that
* subtle differences in floating point precision.

To find out what applies to your case, the only sensible way is, IMHO, to gain experience with the code base in stake. This might be done by inspection, or by occasionally running the tests using a different configuration. And it will take some time, depending of the size of the code base. In a large code base, you will probably find out that there are some parts or components where testing with one configuration is not enough, and others (hopefully the bigger part) do not need more than one configuration for testing.

If you ask which configuration you should prefer for unit testing, then it is IMHO obvious that

* the configuration/platform used by the team in the code\-compile\-test\-debug cycle needs to be the one for which you run the unit tests always
* the configuration(s)/platforms used by your team for deployment should be tested before deployment, especially if you suspect they could behave differently.

You should also make sure everyone in the team is aware of the potential differences, and everyone who used some `#if DEBUG` statement is very careful about not changing any behaviour which could become relevant for testing.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A software development team is working on a C# .NET project with multiple configuration and platform options. They are debating which combination(s) to use for running unit tests during the development stage. Which of the following approaches is most appropriate according to best practices?

A) Always run tests on all configurations (Debug and Release) and all platforms (x86, x64, and Any CPU) to ensure complete coverage.

B) Run tests only on the Debug configuration and Any CPU platform to save time during development.

C) Run tests on the configuration and platform used by the team in their daily development cycle, and occasionally test other combinations to check for potential differences.

D) Alternate between different configurations and platforms randomly for each test run to catch any inconsistencies.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most appropriate approach is to run tests on the configuration and platform used by the team in their daily development cycle, while occasionally testing other combinations. This balances efficiency with the need to catch potential issues across different configurations and platforms. It allows the team to:

1. Focus on the most commonly used setup for quick feedback during development.
2. Detect issues that may only appear in specific configurations or platforms through periodic testing.
3. Adapt their testing strategy based on the specific needs and characteristics of their codebase.
4. Save time during regular development while still maintaining awareness of potential configuration-specific issues.

This approach also aligns with the advice given in the documentation to gain experience with the codebase and identify which parts might require testing across multiple configurations.
